site_title: Brexit at last: Britain leaves the EU for an uncertain future
summary: The United Kingdom officially left the European Union on January 31, 2020, marking the culmination of 47 years of membership. The move, championed by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, has been met with a mix of celebration and relief from some, while others express concerns about the country's economic and global standing. A transition period will keep the UK as a member in all but name until the end of 2020, with negotiations for a free trade agreement with the EU underway. The outcome of Brexit remains uncertain, with potential implications for the UK's sovereignty and its relationships with other countries.

site_title: New app helps match youth with mentors who can offer life advice
summary: A new app, WeConnect, has been launched in Singapore to match youth with mentors offering life advice and guidance on day-to-day challenges. The platform, initiated by the Mentoring Alliance Singapore, aims to recruit 1,000 more volunteer mentors to contribute 100,000 hours of mentoring. The app allows mentors and mentees to connect, communicate, and access training modules and resources. The launch follows the National Mentoring Summit, which also introduced the Asian Centre for Evidence-Based Mentoring, a global network aiming to improve mentoring practices and collaborations.

images.alt_text: Ms Sim Ann, Senior Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth, and Communications and Information, with Mr Sean Ravie (left) and Mr Sean Foo from Youth Guidance Outreach Services at the National Mentoring Summit yesterday.

site_title: Melange of styles
summary: A Singaporean couple, Marina Chang and Kenny Wan, blended Scandinavian, industrial, and pastel themes to create a unique 1,000 sq ft flat in Boon Lay. Interior designer Gwenn Chua from Ethereall helped them achieve this look, incorporating cage lights, sleek black borders, and concrete-look surfaces for industrial inspiration. Neutral tones, light-filled interiors, and wood-like floors and doors reflect Scandinavian aesthetics. The $40,000 renovation took two months to complete and features controlled pastel pops to maintain cohesion and sophistication. The couple moved in in May 2017.

images.alt_text: Island counters are positioned lengthwise to maximise space in the kitchen (above), which also has a mirror to give the illusion of space as well as reflect light to make the area brighter.
The entrance features an industrial-inspired mesh screen (above) above the custom shoe cabinet.
Shipyard-inspired cage lights (above) illuminate the hallway.
The master bedroom (above) sports concrete-like surfaces and is kept simple and clutter-free.

site_title: Yangtze bridge lets people beat Hubei lockdown
summary: People are leaving and entering Hubei province in central China by foot over the Yangtze River Bridge despite a lockdown on vehicle traffic due to the coronavirus epidemic. The move raises doubts over the effectiveness of the lockdown, which aims to contain the pathogen that has killed over 200 people. Pedestrians are allowed to cross the bridge, but those with train tickets booked before the lockdown are exempt. This permeability of the lockdown has sparked concerns about the spread of the virus, particularly among those traveling to cities in the north of China.

images.alt_text: Police standing guard yesterday at a checkpoint at the Jiujiang Yangtze River Bridge that links Hubei province with Jiangxi province in China. The police said people were still entering Hubei and they could still get out, but only in "special circums

site_title: Shoot, run or play to escape
summary: More people are engaging in interactive, real-life gaming experiences, such as live-action role playing, Nerf arenas, and unconventional escape rooms. These activities allow players to physically interact with others and escape from scenarios like zombies. This trend contrasts with the dominance of digital gaming, where players typically interact with screens. The rise of real-life gaming experiences offers a unique way for people to socialize and engage in immersive activities.

images.alt_text: Players blasting “zombies” at the Nerf Action Xperience arena.
A player cracking a puzzle in an escape game held at the Night Safari last year.
A volunteer actor addressing players at a vampire-themed live-action role-playing game last month in a warehouse.

site_title: Football: German clubs lead way in January window, Cavani stays put on deadline day
summary: German clubs have set a new record for spending in the January transfer window, spending €196 million in the Bundesliga. Borussia Dortmund signed 19-year-old striker Erling Braut Haaland from RB Salzburg for around €20 million, while RB Leipzig recruited Spanish under-21 star Dani Olmo for a similar fee. Meanwhile, Paris Saint-Germain held on to striker Edinson Cavani, who was targeted by Atletico Madrid, and instead brought back Belgian winger Yannick Carrasco on loan from Dalian Yifang.

site_title: Help for families with mentally incapacitated members
summary: A joint initiative by the Family Justice Courts and DBS Bank allows families to access emergency funds for mentally incapacitated members. From next Friday, families can file an application for a one-time withdrawal of up to $5,000 at selected POSB branches, with expedited verification and disbursement within three days. This collaboration aims to provide quicker access to funds, balancing convenience and protecting the interests of patients, and is expected to ease the process for families undergoing a challenging transition. The application process requires consent from relevant parties and is piloted at six selected branches.

site_title: First Singaporean infected by Wuhan virus
summary: A 47-year-old Singaporean woman has been confirmed as the first local case of the Wuhan virus, with symptoms appearing after she returned from a family trip to Wuhan on January 30. The woman was asymptomatic when she boarded a flight but developed a fever during medical screening at Changi Airport. She tested positive for the virus and is currently being treated in an isolation room at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases, bringing Singapore's total confirmed cases to 16.

site_title: Torque Shop
summary: New car owners with a double-clutch transmission (DCT) should be mindful of two key situations: never releasing the brake pedal while in D or R gear, as this can cause the clutch to engage and slip. Additionally, selecting a lower gear manually when creeping up a slope can help prevent clutch wear. Proper maintenance, such as oil changes every 40,000km, is also recommended. With proper use, a DCT can last up to 10 years without issues.

site_title: Leave of absence for work pass holders who visited China recently
summary: The Singapore government has implemented measures for work pass holders who visited China recently, requiring a 14-day leave of absence from work to avoid social contact and monitor health closely. New work pass applications from mainland China will be rejected, while renewal applications for existing work pass holders will not be affected. Employers are bracing for a temporary shortage of workers, with some companies considering hiring part-time workers or implementing work-from-home arrangements. The measures aim to prevent the spread of the Wuhan virus in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Below, from left: Ministry of Health director of medical services Kenneth Mak, Communications and Information Minister S. Iswaran, National Development Minister Lawrence Wong, and Immigration and Checkpoints Authority Commissioner Marvin Sim at a new

site_title: MMA: Jiu-jitsu champion Constance Lien's road to success began with hand-written note
summary: Constance Lien, a 20-year-old Singaporean martial artist, has achieved multiple accolades in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, including a world championship title and a gold medal at the SEA Games. Lien's journey began with a handwritten note on her wall, "You will be world champ! #01," which she wrote at the start of 2019. Her determination and focus led to a nomination for The Straits Times Athlete of the Year Award and recognition as Sportsgirl of the Year by the Singapore National Olympic Council. Lien plans to continue training and aims to become a sports psychologist to help athletes with mental health issues.

images.alt_text: Constance Lien won the U-58.5kg title at the 2019 World IBJJF Jiu-Jitsu Championships. ST PHOTO: CHONG JUN LIANG

site_title: STI posts 2.7% weekly fall amid virus worries
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.7% on the week, closing at 3,153.73, amid concerns over the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus. Initial gains were erased as investors focused on rising death tolls and infections. The Asia-Pacific market showed mixed results, with some economies experiencing gains while others, like Hong Kong and South Korea, fell. Medical groups and rubber-glove makers were popular among traders, but tourism and leisure-related stocks took a hit, including Singapore Airlines, which cut capacity into China.

site_title: Wuhan market may not be only source of coronavirus
summary: A Chinese pulmonary disease specialist, Dr. Huang Chaolin, suggests that the Wuhan seafood market may not be the only source of the novel coronavirus outbreak. According to a recent study, only 27 of 41 early cases had direct exposure to the market, while two others had no exposure. This implies that the virus might have been transmitted to humans through multiple sources, but no other sources have been discovered yet. The market, which sold seafood, poultry, and game meat, was shut down on January 1.

site_title: On social media
summary: Hong Kong singer-songwriter-actor Sam Hui, 71, has become a grandfather again after his younger son Scott's wife Ida gave birth to their daughter Leah. The hospital has limited visitors due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Sam Hui and his wife Rebecca Fleming were seen beaming with joy as they held the baby girl. This is Sam Hui's second grandchild, with his elder son Ryan also having twin sons.

site_title: $9k for Chiam See Tong sports fund
summary: The Chiam See Tong Sports Fund Charity Shield 2020 raised approximately $9,000 after 400 fans paid $20 each to watch the Celebrities Sports Club beat the Singapore Ex-Internationals 4-3 at Our Tampines Hub. The event featured celebrities and aimed to support disadvantaged children and youth in achieving their dreams, with all proceeds going to the fund.

images.alt_text: The Chiam See Tong Sports Fund Charity Shield 2020 raised about $9,000 after some 400 fans paid $20 each to watch the Celebrities Sports Club beat the Singapore Ex-Internationals 4-3 at Our Tampines Hub last night. The match featured celebrities like

site_title: Calls grow to ban wildlife trade in Indonesia amid virus outbreak
summary: Calls are growing in Indonesia to ban wildlife trade amid the Wuhan virus outbreak, with animal rights organizations urging President Joko Widodo to take action to mitigate risks. The markets, which sell exotic animals, have been linked to the outbreak and are considered a "perfect breeding ground" for deadly zoonotic viruses. The government has taken measures, including quarantining arriving passengers and tightening security at entry points, but critics say more needs to be done to prevent the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: A wildlife market that sells exotic animals from snakes to bats in Jatinegara, East Jakarta. A coalition of animal rights organisations has urged President Joko Widodo to take measures so Indonesia would not become the next point of origin of a deadl

site_title: Dow ends 2.1% lower as US stocks tumble on virus fears
summary: US stocks tumbled on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average declining 2.1% and the S&P 500 falling 1.8%, due to mounting fears over the coronavirus. At least 213 people have died and nearly 10,000 infected in China, with over 20 countries affected. The US government declared a public health emergency and banned entry to foreign nationals who traveled to China in the past two weeks, while quarantining Americans who made the trip. The outbreak raised concerns about global growth and supply chain disruptions, with losses across various sectors, except for Amazon.

site_title: SportingLife: Making their chances count to be there on final weekend of Australian Open
summary: Dominic Thiem, an Austrian tennis player, prepares to face Alexander Zverev in the Australian Open's final weekend. Thiem, unshaven and focused, waits for Zverev's serve, looking for an opportunity to break and gain an advantage. The match is crucial for Thiem, who is seeking to make the most of his chances to win.

site_title: Van Dijk knows all the Ings and outs
summary: Liverpool defender Virgil van Dijk is confident in his team's chances against Southampton striker Danny Ings, who has scored 14 Premier League goals this season. Despite Ings' impressive form, van Dijk doesn't plan to study his strengths and weaknesses, instead focusing on preparing for the match. Ings will face his former team for the first time since leaving Liverpool in 2018. The match comes as Liverpool look to maintain their 16-game unbeaten streak in the league.

site_title: Chan Ying Jian resigns as BreadTalk's group CFO and CIO
summary: BreadTalk Group announced the resignation of Chief Financial Officer (CFO) and Chief Investment Officer (CIO) Chan Ying Jian, effective March 15. Chan, 37, will leave to pursue other career opportunities after serving since 2015. George Quek, executive chairman and founder, will oversee accounting and financial matters, assisted by the group financial controller and division financial controller. Chan's departure follows CEO Henry Chu's exit for personal and health reasons, and comes after BreadTalk issued a profit guidance indicating a net loss for fiscal 2019 due to weakness in its bakery and food concept divisions.

images.alt_text: Group chief executive officer Henry Chu left the company on Dec 31 for personal and health reasons. Mr Chan Ying Jian, who is both chief financial officer and chief investment officer, will leave BreadTalk Group on March 15.

Group chief executive officer Henry Chu left the company on Dec 31 for personal and health reasons. Mr Chan Ying Jian, who is both chief financial officer and chief investment officer, will leave BreadTalk Group on March 15.

site_title: Pompeo pledges continued US support for Ukraine
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Ukraine, emphasizing Washington's support for the country amidst the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump. Pompeo and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky played down the fallout from the impeachment, with Pompeo stating the US commitment to support Ukraine's struggle for freedom, democracy, and prosperity won't waver. The visit comes as the impeachment trial is likely to acquit Trump, and Ukraine counts on US diplomatic support, sanctions on Moscow, and military aid to combat Russian-backed fighters.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Metropolitan Yepifaniy (second from left), the leader of the new independent Ukrainian Orthodox Church, visiting the Mikhailovsky Zlatoverkhy Cathedral in Kiev yesterday.

site_title: Wuhan virus: US declares coronavirus a public health emergency, bars foreigners who visited China
summary: The US declared a public health emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, banning foreign nationals who have visited China from entering the country. Starting Sunday, US citizens who have visited China's Hubei Province within the last 14 days will be subject to a 14-day quarantine. The administration also limited flights from China to seven US airports. With six confirmed cases in the US and 213 deaths in China, the risk to the US public is considered low. Over 9,800 people in China are infected, and cases have been reported in at least 25 countries.

site_title: Bending nature to our will: Singapore scientists produce sea bass that’s healthier, easier to breed
summary: Singapore scientists have developed a healthier and easier-to-breed Asian sea bass, known as barramundi, through selective genetic traits. Local fish farm Barramundi Asia has acquired a genetic facility to cross-breed the fish for quicker growth, disease resistance, and high omega-3 content. The Asian sea bass has potential as the "salmon of the tropics" due to its adaptability to tropical waters and versatility in various cuisines. This development aims to improve the species for agricultural and ornamental purposes.

images.alt_text: Barramundi Asia's chief executive Andreas von Scholten and Temasek Life Sciences Laboratory's senior principal investigator Yue Genhua (left) and chief executive Peter Chia with a pool of St John's Sea Bass at the laboratory at the National Universit

site_title: China's factories flatlining even before virus outbreak worsened
summary: China's manufacturing sector flatlined in January, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 50, before the coronavirus outbreak worsened. The non-manufacturing gauge remained stable at 54.1. Economists attribute the slowdown to weak domestic demand, a trade war, and a crackdown on debt. The outbreak is now expected to further weaken the economy, with forecasts revised down to 4% GDP growth in the first quarter. Analysts warn of a potential full-year growth of 5% or lower, depending on the duration of the outbreak.

images.alt_text: A factory production line in Zhangjiakou in China's Hebei province. The first official indicator of the Chinese economy this year signalled that it was already slowing amid weak domestic demand, a crackdown on debt and the trade war with the United S

site_title: Developers' worries about oversupply remain: Redas
summary: Singapore's private residential property market showed resilience last year, with 9,900 new homes sold, 12.7% higher than in 2018. Despite concerns over oversupply, developers expect demand to remain steady this year, driven by Housing Board upgraders and pent-up household liquidity. New projects, including over 30 with 9,000 units, are expected to be launched, with a focus on revitalizing existing spaces through partnerships and redevelopment schemes. Minister Lawrence Wong welcomed such partnerships, citing progress in Business Improvement Districts and commercial redevelopment initiatives.

images.alt_text: Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) president Chia Ngiang Hong (from left), Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong, Redas past president Augustine Tan, Ministry of Law deputy secretary Calvin Phua and Inland Revenue Auth

site_title: Jones has 'greatest' aim for Six Nations favourites England
summary: England captain Owen Farrell and coach Eddie Jones aim to make the team the greatest rugby team in the world. Jones recently stated that winning a Grand Slam without exceptional rugby is possible, and he wants to play sustainable, memorable rugby. England, who reached the World Cup final last year, face a tough challenge as they navigate a salary-cap scandal and try to revive morale. The team faces a fresh and youthful French squad under new coach Fabien Galthie, who won the last two Under-20 world titles.

images.alt_text: The captains at a Six Nations launch event last week - France's Charles Ollivon, Italy's Luca Bigi, England's Owen Farrell, Ireland's Jonathan Sexton, Wales' Alun Wyn Jones and Scotland's Stuart Hogg. PHOTO: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

site_title: Virus disruption hits football, women's golf
summary: The coronavirus outbreak has disrupted international sports, with the LPGA Tour cancelling its Blue Bay tournament in China and Olympic football qualifiers in Australia being shuffled. The LPGA Tour cited health concerns and travel restrictions due to the virus. The Asian Football Confederation has also moved the four-team women's football tournament from Wuhan to Australia, with China's team in quarantine. Several international sports events have been affected, including the World Indoor Athletics Championships, boxing and basketball qualifying tournaments, and World Cup skiing races. The World Health Organisation declared the outbreak a public health emergency.

site_title: Bank lending flat in December: MAS data
summary: Bank lending in Singapore was flat in December, dipping 0.05% to $692.4 billion. This follows a 0.5% increase in November. Total borrowing rose 3.1% compared to the same period in 2018, driven by increases in most sectors except agriculture, mining, manufacturing, and transport. Consumer lending edged down 0.1% to $262.79 billion, primarily due to a decline in housing and bridging loans.

site_title: Scoot, SIA and SilkAir slash flights to China amid viral concerns
summary: Singapore Airlines' budget carrier Scoot, along with Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir, has reduced flights to China amid concerns over the Wuhan virus. Scoot will suspend flights to 11 cities in mainland China and reduce frequencies to eight cities, while SIA and SilkAir will also reduce capacity on selected routes. Affected customers will receive full refunds and rebooking options. The moves come as global companies advise employees not to travel to China, citing safety concerns.

site_title: 49Ers' wall is chief concern
summary: The Kansas City Chiefs, led by quarterback Patrick Mahomes, face the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl LIV, their first appearance in 50 years. Mahomes is considered one of the best quarterbacks in the league, but will be up against the 49ers' meanest defense, which has allowed the fewest completions exceeding 20 yards this season. The Chiefs are determined to not repeat their Super Bowl LIV loss, with Mahomes aiming to land his second straight MVP award and a maiden Super Bowl MVP.

site_title: Bryant tribute in All-Star game
summary: The NBA has announced plans for the upcoming All-Star Game on February 16, honoring the late Kobe Bryant. The game will feature mini-games for charity in each quarter, with scores resetting after the second and third periods. The winner will be determined by reaching a target score of 24 points more than the leading team's total in the first three periods. The tribute also includes additional plans to be announced. Chris Paul, a close friend of Bryant's, will play in the game, and tributes are expected at the Lakers' first game since Bryant's death.

site_title: Trainer Burridge to cast keen eye on Lim's Craft and Adipson
summary: Australian trainer Steven Burridge is focusing on his pair of four-year-old horses, Lim's Craft and Adipson, ahead of the Singapore Four-Year-Old Challenge. The pair will compete in today's Class 3 event, with Burridge seeking to gauge their readiness for the three-race series, which includes the $1 million Singapore Derby. Lim's Craft, a Smart Missile colt, and Adipson, a So You Think son, boast good form and will carry significant weights, but Burridge is optimistic about their chances.

images.alt_text: Trainer Steven Burridge says the Singapore Four-Year-Old Challenge is the main target for Lim's Craft and Adipson.

site_title: Inner Flame looks good for third win in a row
summary: Hong Kong racing expert Douglas Whyte is eyeing a third win in a row for his star horse Inner Flame, who is the top pick in Race 9 at Sha Tin. Inner Flame has shown impressive form, including a recent win over this course and distance. Whyte is optimistic about the horse's chances despite a Class 3 field, and Inner Flame appears to have several ratings points still in hand. The horse is set to face competition from Invincible Missile, Island Shine, and Glenealy Generals, but Whyte believes Inner Flame has the potential to take the win.

images.alt_text: Multiple champion jockey-turnedtrainer Douglas Whyte casting an eye on his two-from-two star Inner Flame, who is the top pick in Race 9 at Sha Tin tomorrow.

site_title: 30 weeks' jail sought for man who filmed housemates in shower
summary: A former Yale-NUS College student, 26, pleaded guilty to eight counts of insulting a woman's modesty after filming four female housemates showering in their individual bedrooms. The prosecution urges a minimum 30-week jail sentence to deter future offending, citing the victims' trust and right to safety and privacy. The student was dismissed from college for breaching its code of conduct and posing a safety risk, and faces additional 16 similar charges during sentencing, set for next Friday.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China coronavirus toll rises to 259 with total cases close to 12,000 as US imposes border curbs
summary: China's coronavirus toll has risen to 259 deaths, with a total of 11,791 cases, as the country imposes strict travel and business restrictions. The US, Singapore, and Australia have also restricted entry to foreign nationals who have recently been in China. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern, but has urged countries to focus on mitigation efforts rather than global trade and travel restrictions. Many nations have suspended flights to China, and some companies have closed their operations in the country.

site_title: World Briefs : Man shot dead after taking kids hostage
summary: A man in India took two dozen children hostage at his daughter's birthday party, demanding 10 million rupees in ransom per child. He was shot dead by police after his wife was beaten to death by locals trying to escape. The children, aged 6 months to 13 years, were rescued unharmed.

site_title: Glitch in Singapore Pools' betting systems: More issues surface from software errors
summary: A glitch in Singapore Pools' betting systems has affected iToto and 4-D Quick Pick bets, with errors including the omission of numbers 49, zero, and nine. The issue, which started in 2018, has resulted in 14 Toto draws with 49 as a winning number, and affected 0.04% of Toto sales and 0.0003% of 4-D sales. Affected customers will receive refunds and additional prize winnings, with the Ministry of Home Affairs investigating the incidents.

site_title: In short
summary: Bong Joon-ho's film "Parasite" won Film of the Year and Director of the Year at the 40th London Critics' Circle Film Awards. Meanwhile, Cristiano Ronaldo surpassed 200 million followers on Instagram, becoming the platform's most-followed person, with Ariana Grande and Dwayne Johnson in second and third spots.

site_title: Thai party's possible dissolution risks widening generation gap
summary: Thailand's "red versus yellow" political divide is shifting, with a new fault line emerging between the young and the old. The possible dissolution of the Future Forward Party, the second-largest opposition party, is expected to widen this cleavage. The party's demise may pit the younger generation against the older, more conservative establishment, creating a new and potentially deeper divide in Thai politics.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Feb 1
summary: The US declared a public health emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, barring entry to foreign nationals who have traveled to China. Starting Sunday, US citizens who traveled to China's Hubei Province in the last 14 days will face a mandatory 14-day quarantine. The US also limited flights from China to seven airports. The UK left the EU, marking a significant blow to Europe's unity efforts. Two women were arrested for running security checkpoints near Trump's Florida resort, while a woman testified that Harvey Weinstein raped her. A helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant was found to lack certification for foggy conditions.

site_title: Poly student gets 18 months' probation over upskirt photos
summary: A 19-year-old Nanyang Polytechnic student, Chiang Wei Sheng, was sentenced to 18 months' probation for snapping upskirt photos of six women at different locations. He must remain indoors from 10pm to 6am daily, perform 150 hours of community service, and refrain from owning a mobile phone with camera functions. Chiang pleaded guilty to three counts of insulting a woman's modesty in December last year and was suspended from the polytechnic for two semesters.

images.alt_text: Chiang Wei Sheng must remain indoors from 10pm to 6am every day, and has to do community service.

site_title: Healthy star makes it third-time lucky
summary: Healthy Star, a 3-year-old New Zealand-bred, won the $75,000 Restricted Maiden event at Kranji with an easy all-the-way victory under jockey Ruan Maia. The 1,000m win, in 59.49 seconds, avenged Healthy Star's last two defeats by two Clements-trained gallopers. Trainer Lee Freedman praised Maia's 10-out-of-10 ride, saying the Brazilian jockey "summed it up quickly" and that Healthy Star is promising and could go further.

images.alt_text: Healthy Star giving Brazilian jockey Ruan Maia an armchair ride in Race 2 at Kranji last night. ST PHOTO: SALWA SUANDI

site_title: Paradegoers at Chingay unfazed by Wuhan virus
summary: About 12,000 spectators attended the first night of the Chingay Parade in Singapore, despite concerns over the Wuhan coronavirus. The event featured 6,000 volunteer performers and included thermal scanners, first-aid booths, and measures to screen attendees for fever. Many attendees, including some with family members from China, felt safe and confident in the event's safety protocols, while others took extra precautions such as wearing masks and using hand sanitizers. The parade is expected to draw an estimated 280,000 people over two days.

site_title: The talking is over, but the uncertainty remains
summary: Anti-Brexit protesters demonstrated outside the Houses of Parliament in London on January 30, 2020, amidst uncertainty about the UK's path after a general election. The author, who left Britain in 2017, returned to the country in October 2019 and notes the repeated delays in the election's outcome. The article implies that the outcome of the election will determine the UK's trajectory after Brexit.

site_title: Nassar victims offered $293m in compensation
summary: USA Gymnastics has filed a plan to emerge from bankruptcy, offering $215 million in compensation to survivors of former national team doctor Larry Nassar's abuse. The settlement, which could be increased by $2.125 million from the insurers of Twistars gymnastics club, is seen as inadequate by lawyer John C. Manly, who represents over 200 athletes. The plan also includes benchmarks for enhancing athlete safety, but prospects for approval appear dim.

site_title: Wuhan coronavirus situation claims three Macau race meetings
summary: The Macau Jockey Club has cancelled three upcoming horse racing meetings due to concerns about the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak. The meetings, scheduled for Feb 1, 7, and 9, have been replaced with alternative events in Singapore and Australia. The club prioritizes public hygiene and health, cooperating with the government to fight the disease. Measures include temperature screening, closing betting centers, and exempting employees from work. The club will continue to monitor the situation and work with authorities to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Seungri indicted, without detention
summary: Seungri, a former BigBang singer, was indicted by the Seoul Central District Prosecutors Office for allegedly gambling overseas and procuring prostitutes for investors. He is accused of arranging sex services for investors from Japan, Taiwan, and Hong Kong between 2015 and 2016. The indictment marks a significant step towards a trial, following a court's denial of an arrest warrant two weeks prior. Seungri's alleged offenses pale in comparison to those of fellow singer Jung Joon-young, who received a six-year jail term for gang-rape, and Choi Jong-hoon, who received a five-year jail term.

site_title: 10 must-reads for today
summary: Britain formally leaves the European Union, marking a new chapter in its history. Singapore has banned Chinese passport holders from entry unless they can show recent travel history. A new fault line emerges in Thailand between young and old, as the Future Forward Party is dissolved. Australia declares a state of emergency due to severe fire danger. The US fails to address its China question ahead of the 2020 presidential election. A new app, WeConnect, matches youth with mentors, and a Picasso art exhibition is set to open at National Gallery Singapore.

images.alt_text: Pro-Brexit British Members of European Parliament leaving the European Parliament in Brussels for the last time yesterday.

site_title: Volvo's new XC60 T8 Plug-In Hybrid is a red hot green car
summary: Volvo has introduced its new XC60 T8 Plug-In Hybrid, a spacious and comfortable vehicle. The XC60's lithium-ion battery pack is charged by an external electrical source, increasing efficiency. Unlike traditional hybrids, the XC60 T8 Plug-In Hybrid prioritizes performance, allowing for short bursts of power from both the engine and electric motor. This design aims to minimize energy conservation, providing a more dynamic driving experience.

site_title: Betta in the wild: Plain ancestors of Siamese fighting fish facing extinction
summary: The Siamese fighting fish, a popular pet, is facing extinction due to the decline of its plain ancestors in the wild. The Betta Club Singapore reports that these wild betta populations are dwindling, threatening the genetic diversity of the species. Vice-president Mr. Iven Teh expresses concern over the loss of these wild betta populations, which are being over-relied upon for breeding purposes, leading to inbreeding and reduced genetic variation. Conservation efforts are needed to protect the remaining wild betta populations and preserve the species' genetic diversity.

site_title: 3 stations on Thomson-East Coast Line begin operations
summary: Singapore's Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) has begun operations with three stations - Woodlands North, Woodlands, and Woodlands South - opening at 5:30am. Commuters welcomed the new alternative to crowded feeder buses, with some halving their travel time to work. Trains currently run at 9-minute intervals, slightly longer than other lines, but commuters were not deterred. The line, expected to be fully operational in 2024, will reduce travel time for Woodlands commuters and link neighbourhoods to the Central Business District.

site_title: Singapore to bar visitors with recent travel history to China
summary: Singapore has introduced new measures to curb the spread of the Wuhan virus, including barring visitors with recent travel history to China, suspending visa issuance to Chinese passport holders, and placing individuals returning from China on a 14-day leave of absence. The measures come after the World Health Organization declared a public health emergency of international concern. The aim is to limit new imported cases and reduce the risk of community spread in Singapore, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat promising to provide support for affected businesses and workers in the upcoming Budget statement.

images.alt_text: ST PHOTO: JASON QUAH

site_title: Football: German league leaders Leipzig sign Angelino on loan from Man City
summary: RB Leipzig signed Spanish left-back Angelino on loan from Manchester City for the remainder of the season. The 23-year-old, who has struggled for game-time at Manchester City, will provide reinforcement in defense for the Bundesliga leaders. Leipzig missed out on signing Germany defender Robin Koch, and Angelino moves to the club after previously playing for PSV Eindhoven and Manchester City. The loan deal was finalized before the transfer window closed.

site_title: Australia faces fresh fire threat amid soaring heat, winds
summary: Australia is facing a fresh fire threat due to soaring temperatures and strong winds, with a state of emergency declared in Canberra. The Australian Capital Territory's south is experiencing an out-of-control fire that has grown to 185 sq km, and officials warn it may become unpredictable and uncontrollable. The fire season has already killed 33 people and destroyed 2,500 homes, with temperatures expected to reach extreme heatwave conditions in the south-east this weekend. The federal government has announced a $2 billion energy deal to reduce emissions and lower power bills, but critics argue it is too little, too late.

images.alt_text: Smoke billowing from a bush fire near the town of Tharwa, in the Australian Capital Territory, yesterday. Emergency officials have urged people to prepare for fires in parts of the south-east, including hundreds of kilometres of coast south of Sydney

site_title: American long shot plots final twist
summary: The 2020 Australian Open women's final pits unseeded American Sofia Kenin against unseeded Spaniard Garbine Muguruza, a 750-1 longshot. Kenin, 21, has never made it past the fourth round at a Grand Slam, but has the confidence and courage to challenge Muguruza. The two have met before, with Kenin winning in Beijing last year. Muguruza, a seven-time Grand Slam champion, is the clear favorite, but Kenin's unorthodox style and experience could lead to an upset. The winner will be the first unseeded player to win the Australian Open since 2007.

site_title: Bending nature to our will
summary: Humans have selectively bred plants and animals for centuries, a process known as artificial selection. In Singapore, this is evident in the cultivation of desirable traits in flowers and trees. Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, proposed in his book On The Origin Of Species, explains how organisms adapt to their environments, leading to the inheritance of beneficial traits. This selective breeding continues today, shaping the characteristics of plants and animals for agricultural and ornamental purposes.

site_title: How do bats live with so many viruses?
summary: Research suggests that bats may have an immune system that allows them to coexist with multiple disease-causing viruses, potentially making them the source of the current coronavirus outbreak. Bats are natural reservoirs for various viruses, including SARS, Ebola, and Nipah, and their ability to host multiple viruses without getting sick is due to their weakened immune response. This adaptation, which may have evolved from their ability to fly, allows bats to maintain a "balanced state of effective response" to viruses without overreacting. Understanding how bats carry and survive viruses is crucial in tracing the origin of the outbreak and preventing future ones.

images.alt_text: Bats are considered the probable source of the current coronavirus outbreak spreading from China. Research shows they may have an immune system that lets them coexist with many disease-causing viruses.

site_title: InBrief
summary: Italy declared a six-month state of emergency to combat the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus after two cases were confirmed in Rome. Russia also reported its first cases, with two Chinese citizens testing positive in the country's first cases since the outbreak. Britain confirmed its first cases, with two people from the same family infected. Thailand reported its first case of human-to-human transmission, with a taxi driver likely infected by a sick traveller from China. These developments come as the global coronavirus outbreak continues to spread.

site_title: SIA and Japan's ANA ink pact for more flight, fare options
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and All Nippon Airways (ANA) have signed a partnership pact to boost the Singapore air hub and increase flight options to Japan, Malaysia, Indonesia, India, and Australia. The agreement, if approved, will allow SIA and ANA to pool resources, share networks, and discuss fare pricing and inventory. The partnership is expected to boost revenue and provide passengers with increased flight frequencies, travel conveniences, and shorter layovers, with the potential to increase traffic to and through Changi Airport.

site_title: English to be used to teach maths, science again: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia will once again teach mathematics and science in English, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced. The move reverses a 2012 policy that had taught these subjects in Bahasa Malaysia. Mahathir cited the importance of mastering English for science and math, citing difficulties faced by students who studied in Bahasa Malaysia. The decision aims to improve students' skills in the language and prepare them for adult life, with the goal of promoting national development.

site_title: Pofma invoked against two fake posts on masks, Singaporean cases
summary: Singapore's Government invoked the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) twice to correct false posts about the Wuhan virus, including a claim that five Singaporeans had contracted the virus without going to China. The law was also used to correct a post claiming Singapore had run out of face masks and two posts warning people to avoid Woodlands MRT station due to a suspected case. The Government has lifted temporary exemptions on general correction directions for search engines and social media platforms, and has instructed online platforms to carry correction notices alongside false content.

site_title: Vintage Nordic chic lives on
summary: Vintage Scandinavian furniture, primarily from Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, has gained popularity among collectors for its classic and minimalist designs. Originating in the early 1900s, this "mid-century" style has captivated the world with its simplicity and quality. The designs of Danish architect-designers have set a high standard for the industry, influencing global design trends. Today, vintage Scandinavian furniture remains highly sought after for its storied history and solid construction.

site_title: Brexit uncertainty not the only worry for S'pore firms
summary: Singapore-based security solutions provider Concorde Security transferred its UK operations to a British partner due to Brexit uncertainty, aiming to avoid high labor costs and difficulties in hiring foreign workers post-Brexit. The company's founder, Mr Alan Chua, opted for a licensee relationship to continue selling its security solutions in the UK without the need for direct involvement. This move reflects concerns among Singaporean firms about the impact of the US-China trade war and Brexit on their UK operations, despite some remaining bullish about the UK prospects.

site_title: Stories of 23 business pioneers captured in revamped gallery
summary: The Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall has revamped its Gallery 4 - Chinese Business Pioneers exhibit, showcasing the stories of 23 Chinese business pioneers who contributed to Singapore's development. The gallery features Tan Tock Seng, Tan Kah Kee, and other notable figures, highlighting their values such as integrity, loyalty, and altruism. New interactive features include a digital quiz, a multimedia personality quiz, and an interactive game based on Chinese textbooks from the 1930s to 1940s. The gallery reopened on February 1, 2020, with free admission for Singaporeans and permanent residents.

site_title: More Audi EVs to arrive amid growing interest
summary: Audi plans to introduce more battery-powered models in Singapore, starting with the e-tron SUV, unveiled at the 2020 Singapore Motorshow. The e-tron Sportback, a sleeker version, is expected to follow by year-end. Audi aims to capitalize on the growing interest in electric vehicles in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Mr Markus Schuster, Audi Singapore managing director, with the e-tron, Audi’s first fully electric production SUV, at its launch at the Singapore Motorshow 2020.

site_title: Singapore navy's final three littoral mission vessels now operational
summary: The Republic of Singapore Navy's final three littoral mission vessels, the RSS Fortitude, RSS Dauntless, and RSS Fearless, have been commissioned, joining five other vessels to replace ageing Fearless-class patrol ships. The eight vessels can now be deployed for operations and respond to maritime threats, including piracy and terrorist attacks. Designed and built in Singapore, the LMVs feature improved sensors and easier maintenance, reducing the workload by half compared to the patrol vessels. The commissioning marks an important milestone for Singapore's maritime security, with the navy and Defence Science and Technology Agency working to enhance the vessels' efficiency and capabilities.

site_title: Hyflux hires new legal advisers
summary: Hyflux, a distressed water treatment firm, has appointed Clifford Chance and Cavenagh Law as its new legal advisers after WongPartnership, its previous legal team, applied to discharge itself due to a loss of confidence. Hyflux received another debt moratorium extension until Feb 28 and a hearing has been scheduled for Feb 20 to consider any extensions beyond this date. Middle Eastern utility provider Utico is offering a $400 million rescue package, while a mystery rival suitor, Aqua Munda, has also made an offer to some of Hyflux's creditors, adding to the complexity of the firm's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Manufacturers more upbeat on 1st-half outlook
summary: Manufacturers in Singapore are more optimistic about the first half of the year, with 19% expecting business prospects to improve, according to a quarterly survey by the Economic Development Board. The semiconductor industry is particularly upbeat, driven by demand for 5G technology. In contrast, the services sector has turned bearish, with 14% of firms expecting slower business and only 12% optimistic about conditions. Despite the virus outbreak in China, the impact on manufacturing has been minimal, and experts expect further improvement in the semiconductor industry's prospects.

images.alt_text: A weighted 19 per cent of manufacturing establishments expect business prospects to improve, outnumbering by 12 percentage points those with a softer view, according to the latest quarterly survey by the Economic Development Board.

site_title: Democrats' bid to call witnesses set to fail
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment trial is likely to end in acquittal as a key Republican senator, Lamar Alexander, declared that further evidence is unnecessary, clearing the way for a swift decision. Democrats failed to secure the 51 votes needed to call witnesses, despite efforts to sway some Republicans. Alexander's decision may bring an end to Trump's two-week trial, which is unlikely to result in his conviction. The acquittal would be seen as illegitimate by Democrats, who will likely claim the trial was flawed and that Trump's actions were impeachable.

images.alt_text: Republican Senator Lamar Alexander, who had been undecided, said there is no need for more evidence to prove something that has already been proven and that does not meet the United States Constitution's high bar for an impeachable offence.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Why it is still safe to attend events with large crowds
summary: The Wuhan virus has been deemed not a significant threat in Singapore, allowing people to attend large crowds without taking extraordinary measures. There is currently no community spread of the virus in the country. Experts recommend moving away if someone near you coughs and sneezes without a mask, as they are unlikely to be infected. Surgical masks are not effective in preventing virus transmission and are only necessary for those who are sick to wear in public. Frequent hand washing and proper hygiene practices are advised to prevent the spread of germs.

site_title: Aliff in another fight, estranged wife wants to reconcile for the sake of son
summary: Malaysian singer-actress Bella Astillah is considering reconciling with her estranged husband, Singapore actor-singer Aliff Aziz, for the sake of their 3-year-old son Ayden. Aliff has been involved in another incident, being chased and arrested for disorderly behavior. Despite his troubled past, Bella is willing to forgive and forget if Aliff prioritizes their son's well-being. She believes that if Aliff truly loves and cares for Ayden, that's enough for her to consider patching things up.

images.alt_text: Malaysian singer-actress Bella Astillah with Ayden (both above), her son with Singapore actor-singer Aliff Aziz, in an Instagram post where she included a Chinese New Year greeting.

Malaysian singer-actress Bella Astillah with Ayden, her son with Singapore actor-singer Aliff Aziz (above, in a videograb of the latest incident in Geylang), in an Instagram post where she included a Chinese New Year greeting.

site_title: Wuhan party chief admits city should have acted sooner
summary: Wuhan's Communist Party chief, Ma Guoqiang, has admitted that the city should have taken measures to contain the novel coronavirus sooner, potentially reducing the impact on China and the world. If measures had been implemented on January 12-13, the situation might not be as severe now. Wuhan is under an unprecedented lockdown, with inadequate medical resources, and the city's Mayor, Zhou Xianwang, described the task as "severe and complex." Over 9,600 cases have been reported in China, with at least 213 deaths, and over 130 confirmed cases in 23 countries.

images.alt_text: Passengers waiting to board a flight yesterday at Rome's Fiumicino airport, as a number of airlines halted or reduced flights to China in a bid to contain the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus. China sent two planes to Malaysia and Thailand yesterday t

site_title: Telescope shows Sun's surface in detail
summary: A new telescope installed on a volcano in Hawaii has captured the highest resolution image of the Sun's surface, revealing turbulent, "boiling" gas and magnetic field markers. The Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope, featuring a 4m mirror, has provided images of features as small as 30km across. The telescope's advanced cooling system and adaptive optics enable better heat protection and atmospheric compensation. Studying the Sun's activity can help predict space weather, including disruptions to satellites, GPS, and power grids, and ultimately improve forecasters' ability to predict solar storms.

images.alt_text: This picture taken by the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope shows the highest resolution image of the Sun's surface ever captured. It reveals a pattern of turbulent, "boiling" gas covering the entire Sun.

site_title: Mask distribution to begin at 200 RC centres today
summary: Singapore is distributing over 5 million masks to local households, starting today at 200 residents' committee (RC) centres. The distribution aims to provide one-time use masks for people who are ill to avoid infecting others amid the spread of the Wuhan virus. Collection times will be staggered to prevent long queues, and residents can check details on community notice boards, digital display panels, and constituency social media platforms. The masks are expected to be fully distributed by Feb 9, with PA volunteers delivering to residents with mobility issues.

site_title: Friday's South Africa results
summary: South Africa horse racing results were released on Friday, with several notable wins. In Race 1, Herrin took first place, while in Race 2, Verbarium won. In Race 3, Real Rascal emerged victorious, followed by wins in Races 4 (Pomaceous) and 5 (Outlandos D'amour). In Race 6, Celestial Prince took the top spot, and Mangrove won in Race 7. The results of Race 8 were not available at press time.

site_title: Ushering in CNY with 'lucky coins' and lion dance
summary: DBS Group and OCBC Centre hosted events to celebrate Chinese New Year, amidst concerns over the Wuhan virus. DBS distributed "lucky gold coins" and screened temperatures, while reducing food waste by 20% and donating unserved food to foreign workers. Meanwhile, an OCBC Centre branch staged a lion dance performance featuring traditional martial art "mei hua zhuang". These events aimed to usher in the Year of the Rat while taking precautions to mitigate the virus threat. Both banks marked their annual lion dance showcases to welcome the new year.

summary: The Nissan Leaf Nismo RC, an electric racing car, boasts 322hp and 640Nm of torque, reaching 100kmh in 3.4 seconds. Meanwhile, Subaru unveiled the XV e-Boxer, a compact all-wheel-drive hybrid, and Audi plans to install over 4,500 electric vehicle charging points in its company parking spaces by 2022. Other automotive news includes the new Seat Leon, Toyota's electrification plans, and Jaguar's lease of I-Pace crossovers for British healthcare staff.

site_title: Grab co-founder, Sea founder join EDB board
summary: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling and Sea founder Forrest Li have joined the Economic Development Board (EDB) board, along with deputy director-general of education Liew Wei Li. They join representatives from traditional industries and reappointed members, including ExxonMobil's regional chairman and Procter & Gamble's president. The new additions aim to bring diverse perspectives to the 16-member board, which oversees Singapore's economic development and innovation initiatives.

images.alt_text: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling (top) and chairman and chief executive of Internet platform Sea Forrest Li (above) are two of the three new faces to join the EDB board today.

site_title: Football: Premier League clubs hold fire in quiet transfer window
summary: The January transfer window for Premier League clubs ended with minimal activity, despite the month's biggest move being Manchester United's capture of Bruno Fernandes for €80 million. Total spending by English clubs was £180 million, down from the record £430 million in 2018. Other clubs, such as Chelsea, Tottenham, and Wolves, struggled to find suitable signings, while Liverpool and Sheffield United made some additions to bolster their squads. The window's lack of activity may indicate that clubs are wary of overpaying in a seller's market, with the mid-season window seen as an undesirable time to do business.

site_title: Mini's electric Cooper SE: Big fun in a small package
summary: Mini's electric Cooper SE retains the brand's DNA, despite a new drivetrain. The Cooper SE features unique 17-inch wheels called Corona Spoke 2-tone and a digital instrument cluster. Its styling still dominates with a circular centre console. The electric model combines agility, usable space, and an eager personality, maintaining the brand's identity.

site_title: China trade agency offers 'excuse' certificates to firms hit by outbreak
summary: China's China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) has announced that businesses in China can now request "force majeure" certificates due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. These certificates can excuse parties from non-performance of contractual obligations. The move aims to safeguard Chinese companies' rights and interests, and help reduce losses. Applicants must provide proof of transportation delays and export contract cancellations. The certification is recognized and accepted overseas, offering a solution for Chinese companies affected by the outbreak. This move follows the World Health Organization's global emergency declaration over the deadly coronavirus.

site_title: Redesign Paya Lebar Air Base as town of the future in URA competition
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a competition, "Runway For Your Imagination," to redesign the 800ha Paya Lebar Air Base site in Singapore. The public can submit ideas on how to redevelop the site after the airbase relocates to 2030. The competition, in partnership with the Singapore Institute of Architects and the Singapore Institute of Planners, offers prizes up to $5,000 for the open category and up to $3,000 for tertiary students. Participants can choose from three themes: Concept Master Plan, Transforming The Runway, and Rejuvenating Paya Lebar Airport.

site_title: US Senate sets final Trump impeachment trial vote for Feb 5 with no witnesses
summary: The US Senate voted 51-49 to block witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial, setting the stage for a final vote on February 5. The decision, largely along party lines, was seen as a significant blow to the Democratic-led effort to gather more evidence. With 67 votes needed to convict Trump, it's expected he will be easily acquitted. The Senate will reconvene on February 3 for closing arguments, with the final vote to follow.

site_title: Hubei community in Singapore rallies to help those back home
summary: A community of Hubei natives in Singapore, led by a 19-year-old student, Xi Wang, has raised $61,000 to send medical supplies to hospitals in Wuhan, China. The funds were used to purchase essential items and shipped via Shanghai's Pudong airport. This act of kindness aims to support those affected by the ongoing health crisis in Wuhan. The community's efforts demonstrate the strong bonds of friendship and solidarity among Hubei natives worldwide.

site_title: 3 more cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing total to 16
summary: Singapore has reported three more cases of the Wuhan virus, bringing the total to 16. The new cases include a 31-year-old Chinese national who arrived on Jan 26 and a 38-year-old Chinese national who arrived on Jan 22. A 47-year-old Singaporean woman was also confirmed as the 15th case, having been evacuated from Wuhan on Thursday. All three cases are in stable condition, and there is currently no evidence of community spread in Singapore.

site_title: Fox Chilwell mulls over Chelsea move
summary: Chelsea manager Frank Lampard is reportedly considering signing Foxes left-back Ben Chilwell to bolster his defense. Chilwell is one of three left-back options Lampard has, but is likely the top choice due to his quality. The 24-year-old has impressed in the Premier League and could provide the Blues with the depth they need to compete. Lampard is set to decide on a fourth left-back option, with Chilwell being the preferred choice.

site_title: In love with mid-century Danish Modern furniture
summary: Ms. Lynette Wong, owner of 1B2G Fine Vintage Furniture, has been collecting Danish mid-century vintage pieces for 14 years. She stocks an eclectic collection of furniture, lighting, and more. Wong invites customers to sit on her chairs, showcasing her passion for the style. Despite having a large collection, she believes she still has a long way to go in her pursuit of Danish Modern pieces.

images.alt_text: Ms Lynette Wong started 1B2G Fine Vintage Furniture (above) in Tan Boon Liat Building, where she stocks an eclectic collection of Danish mid-century vintage pieces, from furniture to lighting.

site_title: Britain begins new chapter as it says farewell to EU
summary: Britain officially exits the 28-member European Union at 7am Singapore time, marking a new chapter in its history. The 11-month transition period begins, allowing Britons to work and trade freely with EU nations until December 31. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to lead the country to a bright, new future, while European leaders warn that Britain cannot expect the same access to the single market without adopting EU standards. The UK will no longer be represented in EU institutions, and a new trade deal with the EU is still to be negotiated.

images.alt_text: Pro-Brexit badges on a Union Jack suit in London yesterday. Britain officially exits the 28-member bloc at 7am Singapore time today.
Pro-Brexit supporters at Parliament Square in London yesterday. Britain begins an 11-month transition period after its exit from the European Union. PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Economist who tallied $55b Sars cost sees bigger hit from Wuhan virus
summary: A global cost of the coronavirus could be three to four times that of the 2003 Sars outbreak, which affected the world's economy by $40 billion. Economist Warwick McKibbin calculates this due to China's larger economy and the insidious nature of the new coronavirus, which often presents mild symptoms and can go undetected. The impact will be mostly felt through changes in human psychology, with panic being a major drain on the economy. Analysts predict a significant hit to China's growth and global economies, with some countries, like Hong Kong, expected to suffer a notable impact.

site_title: Indonesian firm makes trading debut - SGX's first of the year
summary: Indonesian firm Resources Global Development (RGD) made its trading debut on Catalist in Singapore, opening at 21 cents and closing at 22 cents, 5% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of 20 cents. The company raised $1.6 million from the IPO to fund general working capital purposes. RGD plans to expand its customer base and geographical coverage, marking the start of a strategic journey for the company, now valued at around $18 million.

site_title: Art shows featuring Picasso, Matisse to be held here
summary: Art lovers in Singapore can view works by renowned artists Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, and Nam June Paik in four special international art exhibitions over the next four years. The exhibitions, a collaboration between the Singapore Tourism Board and National Gallery Singapore, will introduce global art movements and artistic pioneers to the region. The first exhibition, Matisse & Picasso, opens in May, while a Nam June Paik exhibition will take place in October. The events aim to reinforce Singapore's standing as the gateway to the visual arts scene in South-east Asia and strengthen relationships with international museums.

site_title: WHO declares public health emergency, warns of virus spreading undetected
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared a global public health emergency due to the accelerating coronavirus outbreak, citing concerns that the virus could spread undetected in countries with weak health systems. This is the WHO's fifth declaration since 2007, following swine flu, polio, Zika, and two Ebola outbreaks. The declaration allows for global recommendations but does not have the force of law, and the WHO urged countries to keep borders open to prevent disruptions. The WHO praised China's response to the outbreak, with Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stating that China is setting a new standard for outbreak response.

images.alt_text: (From left) The World Health Organisation's health emergencies programme head Michael Ryan, director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and emergency committee chair Didier Houssin at a news conference in Geneva on Thursday, when the WHO declared the

site_title: Jay Chou's shows in HK postponed
summary: Hong Kong Disneyland has postponed Jay Chou's six concerts, initially scheduled for December, due to the Hong Kong protests. The outdoor events are now set for November, pending negotiations with the Hong Kong government and Disneyland. The postponement was also influenced by the Wuhan virus epidemic, with other concerts in Hong Kong and mainland China cancelled. Chou and his wife have donated 3 million yuan to the Hubei Charity Federation to aid in the fight against the virus.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson ordered to pay $469m in pelvic mesh suit
summary: A US judge ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $469 million for false and deceptive marketing of pelvic mesh products, used by tens of thousands of women in California. The products, designed to support weakened pelvic muscles, were found to cause severe side effects, including incontinence, infection, and chronic pain. The company knew of the risks before launch but failed to disclose them. This is the first court ruling to find Johnson & Johnson engaged in illegal false and deceptive business practices, with over 2 million women worldwide affected by the products.

site_title: Singaporean husband evacuated, but wife stuck in Wuhan with baby
summary: A Singaporean permanent resident and Chinese national, Ms H, was evacuated from Wuhan, China, after her husband was cleared to leave due to the COVID-19 outbreak. She had traveled to Wuhan with her 3-month-old baby to reunite with extended family for Chinese New Year. However, her husband was deemed fit to leave, while she was left behind, and she is now stranded in Wuhan with her baby, awaiting further instructions.

images.alt_text: Below left: French citizens on board an evacuation plane yesterday at Wuhan airport bound for south-eastern France. Below right: Flight attendants donning surgical masks at Brisbane International Airport in Australia yesterday.
Left: Employees of a funeral parlour disinfecting a colleague after they transported a body from a hospital in Wuhan, in China's Hubei province, on Thursday.

Below left: French citizens on board an evacuation plane yesterday at Wuhan airport bound for south-eastern France. Below right: Flight attendants donning surgical masks at Brisbane International Airport in Australia yesterday.

site_title: Probation for youth who molested sister, 12
summary: An 18-year-old was sentenced to 21 months' probation for repeatedly asking his 12-year-old sister to engage in obscene acts and molestation. He pleaded guilty to two counts of outraging her modesty and agreed to 150 hours of community service, while his mother was bonded $5,000 to ensure his good behavior. The girl now lives with her grandmother, and the incident led to the family moving to a new home. The case highlights the severity of molestation charges, with offenders facing up to five years in jail and corporal punishment.

site_title: British PM Boris Johnson heralds Brexit as opportunity for 'renewal and change'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed Brexit as an opportunity for "renewal and change" in a speech ahead of the UK's formal departure from the European Union. Johnson called on the nation to come together, saying Britain will "grow in confidence" and "unleash the full potential" of the country. He extended a hand of friendship to the EU, while also vowing to set Britain's own rules and laws. The UK's departure marks a personal triumph for Johnson, who must now navigate 11 months of talks to agree a trade deal before a transition period ends on December 31.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Man who works at coronavirus-hit firm is Germany's seventh case
summary: Germany confirmed its seventh coronavirus case, a man working at a Bavarian company where five others had previously tested positive. The sixth case was identified as the child of the man, bringing the total to seven in Bavaria. The Bavarian Health Ministry announced that details of the seventh patient would be released on Saturday. This marks the first cases of coronavirus in Germany.

site_title: Fernandes is 'new Scholes'
summary: Manchester United has signed Bruno Fernandes in a 5.5-year deal worth €55 million, with the option to rise to €80 million. The 25-year-old midfielder, who played for Sporting Lisbon, has been likened to club legend Paul Scholes by manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who believes he can do "absolutely everything" on the pitch. Fernandes was inspired by Cristiano Ronaldo, his Portugal teammate, and aims to follow in his footsteps, seeking to bring success and trophies to the club. He is expected to inject creativity into United's midfield.

images.alt_text: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer with Manchester United's new signing, Bruno Fernandes (right). His 51/2 year deal is worth an initial €55 million (S$82.9 million), possibly rising to €80 million with add-ons. PHOTO: TWITTER/ MANUTD

site_title: I'm motivated every single day by Kobe's attitude
summary: Delvin Goh, co-captain of the Singapore national basketball team, shares how former NBA star Kobe Bryant's attitude and legacy have motivated him throughout his basketball career. Goh, 24, had a profound impact on his career after meeting Bryant at a clinic in 2011, citing Bryant's "Mamba Mentality" as a key factor in his success. Bryant's passing at 41 has left a lasting impact on Goh and others, with many praising Bryant's on-court achievements and off-court persona as a good friend and father.

images.alt_text: Anticlockwise from right: The late icon Kobe Bryant on Singapore national basketball co-captain Delvin Goh's mobile phone wallpaper. A 16-year-old Goh, on Bryant's left, with other local players at the NBA star's basketball clinic at Marina Bay Sands

site_title: Temperature checks and other measures at Meet-the-People Sessions
summary: Singapore has rolled out measures at Meet-the-People Sessions, including temperature checks, hand sanitizing, and travel declarations, amid the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak. All visitors to PAP branches will be asked to declare if they have traveled to China in the last 14 days and have symptoms such as fever or cough. Residents with recent travel history or symptoms will be advised to return home and contact their branch. Despite the measures, constituency events, including MPSes, will continue as planned, with MPs reassuring that residents seem calm and generally unaffected by the outbreak.

site_title: Singapore has to stay vigilant, but has every reason to be confident: PM Lee
summary: Singapore remains vigilant but confident in its ability to overcome the Wuhan virus outbreak, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The country has plans in place and has not reached the point of community spread, with 16 confirmed cases, mostly Chinese nationals. Lee emphasized the importance of being watchful but also confident, noting that Singapore has prepared for such a situation since the 2003 Sars crisis. The Government is taking measures to help businesses and Singaporeans, and Lee urged against anti-Chinese sentiments, stressing that the virus can affect anyone.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Health Minister Gan Kim Yong (second from left) visiting the National Centre for Infectious Diseases yesterday to observe the screening and containment process for patients affected by the Wuhan virus. With them was

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Health Minister Gan Kim Yong (second from left) visiting the National Centre for Infectious Diseases yesterday to observe the screening and containment process for patients affected by the Wuhan virus. With them was

site_title: Some S'poreans working in China make plans to return home earlier
summary: Singaporeans working in China are planning to return home earlier due to the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak. With Singapore imposing restrictions on travelers with recent China connections, some are taking precautions, including Eric Kng, who wants to return to Singapore within a week. Others, like the Peh family, have already returned early, canceling appointments to minimize risk. Both Kng and the Peh family have businesses affected by the outbreak, with operations temporarily halted. Singapore's restrictions include a 14-day leave of absence for those returning from China.

site_title: Democratic witness bid seems doomed in Trump impeachment trial as Republican Lisa Murkowski says no
summary: Democratic witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial appear doomed after Republican Senator Lisa Murkowski announced opposition to calling witnesses, potentially paving the way for his expected acquittal. Murkowski stated that the impeachment charges were "rushed and flawed" and that she doesn't believe a fair trial can be held in the Senate. A two-thirds majority is required to remove Trump, and with only two moderate Republicans supporting witnesses, Democrats are unlikely to secure the necessary votes. The Senate is set to vote on the issue later in the day, with some senators suggesting the final vote may be held next week.

site_title: Follow doctors' advice and what's best for us as a community: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong advised citizens to follow doctors' advice for protecting themselves from the Wuhan virus. He emphasized the importance of good hand hygiene and warned that masks can create a false sense of security. The government has a sufficient supply of masks, but excessive use could lead to shortages. Lee also noted that the virus behaves differently from SARS and is not as lethal, with a lower death rate. The government is taking preventive steps to mitigate the risk of community spread.

site_title: Worker killed in collapse of Russian sports complex
summary: A worker died on January 31 in Saint Petersburg, Russia, when a decades-old sports complex collapsed during a planned deconstruction operation. The facility's shell collapsed while workers were dismantling its roof, with one worker cutting a piece of concrete when the building came crashing down. The victim attempted to escape but fell into a cloud of dust. The Investigative Committee is investigating the incident to determine the cause, and a colleague witnessed the accident from a safety cage.

site_title: Brexit is 'historic warning sign' for Europe, says France's Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron described Brexit as a "historic warning sign" for the European Union, calling it a reflection of the EU's inability to address internal problems. Macron argued that the UK's departure was made possible by EU members' tendency to blame the EU for their own issues. He emphasized the need for "more Europe" to counter competition from China and the US. Macron expressed concerns about the future relationship between the UK and EU, warning that it won't be the same as the previous decades-long partnership.

site_title: Trump to expand travel ban to six additional countries, says US official
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to issue an expanded version of his travel ban, affecting thousands of immigrants from six additional countries: Eritrea, Kyrgyzstan, Myanmar, Nigeria, Sudan, and Tanzania. The ban will suspend issuance of visas leading to permanent residency and diversity visas, citing security and information-sharing standards not met by these countries. The move is expected to reignite debate over whether the policy discriminates against Muslims, with critics arguing it disproportionately targets Muslim-majority nations.

site_title: Football: Arteta 'happy' with Arsenal's transfer window dealings
summary: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta expressed satisfaction with the club's transfer window dealings, having signed Pablo Mari and Cedric Soares to bolster the defense and retained Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang despite reported interest from Barcelona. Arteta praised the new signings, citing Mari's defensive balance and Soares' experience, while also highlighting Aubameyang's commitment to the club. The manager acknowledged the challenges of working within the club's financial constraints but believes the additions will strengthen the team.

site_title: Basketball: Helicopter in Kobe Bryant crash lacked certificate to fly in fog
summary: A helicopter owned by Island Express Helicopters, which crashed and killed Kobe Bryant and eight others, was not certified to fly in foggy conditions. The helicopter, equipped for instrument flying, was operating under visual flight rules, requiring pilots to see outside the aircraft. The pilot, Ara Zobayan, was licensed for instrument flying but likely had little experience due to the company's limitations. The National Transportation Safety Board will release a preliminary report in 10 days, which may determine if Zobayan was flying on instruments at the time of the crash.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Hackers exploiting fear of bug to target computers, gadgets
summary: Hackers in Singapore are exploiting fear of the coronavirus to target computers and gadgets with malicious e-mail attachments and links. The Singapore Computer Emergency Response Team issued an alert warning of the scam, which aims to install the Emotet malware. Emotet, first discovered in 2014, is designed to steal financial information and spy on victims. The attack has been most active in Japan, where scam e-mails mimic official notifications from public health centers. Experts warn that the attack could spread as people remain worried about the health crisis.
