site_title: Accuser Jessica Mann says Harvey Weinstein raped her, likens former producer to 'Jekyll and Hyde'
summary: Harvey Weinstein, 67, is on trial in New York City, accused of raping Jessica Mann and sexually assaulting Mimi Haleyi. Mann testified that Weinstein raped her in a hotel room in 2013 after a relationship began with her in 2012. She likened Weinstein to "Jekyll and Hyde," describing him as charming in public but violent when alone. The trial is a milestone in the #MeToo movement, with over 80 women accusing Weinstein of sexual misconduct since 2017. Weinstein has pleaded not guilty to all charges.

site_title: British flags taken down at EU buildings in Brussels ahead of Brexit
summary: British flags were removed from EU buildings in Brussels on January 31, ahead of the UK's departure from the European Union at midnight on January 31. The Union Jack was taken down from the European Council and European Parliament buildings, and replaced with the EU flag. The move marks the UK's exit from the bloc after 47 years, with 27 remaining member states regarding it as a third country. The British embassy's EU flag was also removed, and the building's nameplate will be replaced on Saturday, with the UK Mission to the European Union taking its place.

site_title: Wuhan virus: K-pop boy band Got7's Singapore concert on Feb 22 postponed
summary: K-pop boy band Got7's Singapore concert on Feb 22 has been postponed due to concerns over the Wuhan virus outbreak. The concert, originally scheduled at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, will not take place as planned. Live Nation Singapore announced the postponement, citing the safety of artists, patrons, and staff as their top priority. Customers who bought tickets will receive a full refund. This is the latest in a series of concerts to be postponed in the region due to the outbreak, following cancellations by other K-pop acts such as Taeyeon and NCT Dream.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Swedish health authority says woman is confirmed to have coronavirus
summary: Sweden's Public Health Agency confirmed a woman's positive test for coronavirus on January 31, 2020, after she visited Wuhan, China and experienced cough symptoms upon arrival. The woman, not severely ill, is being isolated at a hospital in southern Sweden. This marks the country's first confirmed case. The agency assesses the risk of spread as low, citing experiences from other countries. The global death toll from the virus reached 213, prompting the World Health Organisation's declaration of a global health emergency.

site_title: Japan panel recommends ocean release for radioactive Fukushima water
summary: A Japanese panel recommends releasing radioactive Fukushima water into the Pacific Ocean, a move likely to alarm neighboring countries. The decision, based on past practice, is expected to be accepted by the government. The recommendation comes as Tokyo Electric, the plant's operator, faces a storage crisis, with nearly 1.2 million tonnes of contaminated water set to run out of room by 2022. Neighboring South Korea has retained a ban on imports from the Fukushima region, with athletes planning to bring their own radiation detectors to the Olympics, which are set to take place in Tokyo this summer.

site_title: Germany wants to conclude Brexit talks by year's end: Minister
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Peter Altmaier stated that the country aims to conclude Brexit talks by the end of this year. Altmaier emphasized that the negotiations will prioritize strengthening and reforming the European Union. The UK officially left the EU on January 31, entering a transition period where current EU rules will remain in place while negotiations on a new relationship begin. German officials will represent European interests and ensure a good relationship with Britain, while also protecting vital European interests.

site_title: Hanging of Delhi bus gang rapists postponed
summary: The hanging of four men convicted of a 2012 gang rape in Delhi has been postponed until further orders. The executions were scheduled for February 1, but a court ruled that the hangings would not proceed due to ongoing legal appeals, including mercy petitions to the Indian President. The victims' families, including the mother of the 23-year-old physiotherapy student who died from her injuries, expressed disappointment but vowed to continue fighting for justice. The delay is seen as a rare reprieve, with public support for the executions appearing overwhelming in India and among political parties.

site_title: Football: Spurs not keen on short-term striker options, says Mourinho
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Jose Mourinho stated that the club will not pursue a short-term striker solution to address Harry Kane's injury, which sidelines him until April. Despite transfer links, Mourinho expressed satisfaction with the club's transfer business, which included signing Netherlands winger Steven Bergwijn for €30 million. Bergwijn is seen as a long-term addition to the team, and Mourinho believes he will be useful for the future, potentially playing with Kane together in the future. The club will instead focus on adapting with the current squad.

site_title: Athletics: World Athletics bans prototype shoes after Nike Vaporfly controversy
summary: World Athletics has banned the use of prototype shoes in competition, effective April 30, 2020, after a series of world records were set by athletes wearing Nike Vaporfly trainers. The ban applies to shoes with more than one rigid embedded plate or blade, but allows shoes with spikes to have an additional plate for attaching spikes. The move aims to preserve the integrity of elite competition and prevent unfair advantages. The ban affects athletes like Eliud Kipchoge, who wore a prototype with three carbon blades in his record-breaking attempt in Vienna last October.

site_title: PM Johnson hails 'new dawn' as Britain bids farewell to EU
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has marked the country's departure from the European Union, ending nearly 50 years of integration with Europe. As the UK goes it alone, Johnson has promised to unite the country in a new era of prosperity. A 12-month transition period allows for free movement of people and goods with EU nations until December, but legally, Britain is out with no easy way back. Johnson must now negotiate a new partnership, covering trade, security, and more, with a deadline looming on Monday.

site_title: Two women arrested after running checkpoints near Trump's Florida resort
summary: Two women, Hannah Roemhild, 30, and an unidentified accomplice, were arrested in Florida after leading police on a high-speed chase through the town of Palm Beach. The chase began after Roemhild, who was driving a black SUV, crashed through two security checkpoints near Mar-a-Lago, President Donald Trump's resort. Roemhild, who had a Connecticut driver's license, was driving recklessly and appeared impaired, leading police to fire on the vehicle. She faces charges of assault on a federal officer, deadly assault on a sheriff's deputy, and various traffic charges.

site_title: Indonesia deports US journalist after alleged visa violation, says employer
summary: Indonesia deported US journalist Philip Jacobson, 30, to the US after he was detained on Dec 17, 2019, for allegedly violating his visa. Jacobson, who worked for Mongabay, was initially arrested and faced up to five years in prison for visiting the country with the wrong visa. However, the US State Department said it had been in frequent communication with Jacobson and the charges were formally dropped before his deportation. Jacobson was "temporarily blacklisted" by the country and had repeatedly entered and left Indonesia on a non-journalist visa, according to officials in Borneo.

site_title: What can you expect at the roving On Paper: Singapore before 1867 exhibition at NLB’s public libraries?
summary: A roving exhibition, "On Paper: Singapore before 1867," is touring Singapore's public libraries until March 2020. The exhibit showcases how Singapore was marked on old maps, revealing how the city was viewed by the rest of the world from the 15th century. Visitors can cast their votes for their favorite shape of Singapore from old maps and learn about the city's history. The exhibition will be held at various libraries, including Woodlands Regional Library, Queenstown Public Library, Bedok Public Library, and Jurong Regional Library.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Singaporean husband evacuated home, but wife, infant son stranded in China
summary: A Singaporean woman and her infant son remain stranded in Wuhan, China, after the city was locked down on January 23. The lockdown, announced by Chinese authorities, has restricted airport, train station, and public transport access. The woman, a permanent resident and Chinese national, had planned to spend three weeks in Wuhan with her extended family before returning to Singapore on January 24. Her husband was evacuated home, but she and her son remain in Wuhan, awaiting further instructions.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China's UN ambassador says no need for 'unnecessary panic'
summary: China's UN ambassador Chen Xu said there's no need for "unnecessary panic" as the country controls the novel coronavirus outbreak, which has killed 213 people and infected nearly 10,000 in China. Despite the World Health Organization (WHO) declaring a global health emergency, China's measures, including quarantining 50 million people, have prevented significant spread of the virus beyond China's borders. Chen urged countries to reconsider excessive measures like border closures and travel restrictions, saying they could be counterproductive and accelerate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Netflix's The Crown bowing out after fifth season, with Imelda Staunton to play queen
summary: Netflix's The Crown will end after its fifth season, with Imelda Staunton set to play Queen Elizabeth II. Creator Peter Morgan initially envisioned six seasons but believes it's time to conclude the period drama. The fifth season will follow Staunton, replacing Olivia Colman, who won a Golden Globe for her performance. Morgan cited the development of the fifth season as the reason for ending the show, stating it's the "perfect time and place to stop." The Crown's conclusion marks a new chapter for the series.

site_title: Delhi shooter was quiet teenager who pushed Hindu cause online
summary: A 17-year-old boy from a small north Indian town shot and wounded an anti-government protester in New Delhi, sparking fears of violence in the country. The boy, who cannot be named, was described as quiet and ordinary, and had expressed admiration for a right-wing activist who police accuse of fomenting violence. The incident occurred amid protests against a new citizenship law that has divided opinion, with the Hindu majority and Muslim minority often taking opposing sides. The boy's motivations and how he acquired the gun are unclear, and he is being held in custody.

site_title: Indonesian cops seize 300kg of meth in biggest drug haul
summary: Indonesian police have seized nearly 300kg of crystal methamphetamine in the country's largest drug haul. The seizure was made after three suspects were gunned down in a shoot-out on a toll road in Jakarta on January 30. The drug, valued at $86 million, was hidden in 18 white sacks and transported from the Merak seaport. This is the second major seizure in two months, following the seizure of 210kg in December. The Indonesian government has declared a war on drugs, with dozens of offenders having been executed for trafficking.

site_title: Brexit Britain cuts loose from EU with joy, anger and indifference
summary: The United Kingdom officially leaves the European Union on January 31, 2020, marking a significant moment in its history. The departure is met with a mix of joy, anger, and indifference, with some celebrating British independence and others expressing concerns about the economic and political implications. EU leaders, including Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron, warn that leaving the EU will be worse than staying, while British Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls it a moment of "real national renewal and change." The UK must now chart its own course, with a promised free trade agreement with the EU by the end of 2020.

site_title: Scandinavian furniture sought after by collectors for classic looks, storied designs and solid quality
summary: Vintage Scandinavian furniture, primarily from Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, has gained popularity among collectors for its classic looks and solid quality. Influencing global design since the early 1900s, mid-century minimalist designs from the turn of the century to the 1960s captivated the world, particularly the work of Danish architect-designers who set the standard for design excellence. This style continues to be sought after today.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Work pass holders returning from mainland China must take 14-day leave of absence
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry has implemented measures to restrict workers returning from mainland China, requiring those who have traveled in the past two weeks to take a 14-day leave of absence. New work pass applications for workers from mainland China will be rejected. Employers are also advised to hire part-time help and take precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. The measures aim to mitigate the temporary shortage of workers caused by the Wuhan virus outbreak.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Russia reports first coronavirus cases, restricts China air travel
summary: Russia reported its first two cases of coronavirus on January 31, 2020, and restricted direct flights to China, its largest trade partner, due to rising prices for medical masks and anti-virus medicine. The two infected individuals, Chinese nationals, are in a stable condition and being quarantined. Russia will halt direct flights to China, except for those operated by its national airline, Aeroflot. The country also plans to suspend the issuance of work visas for Chinese nationals, evacuate over 600 Russian citizens from Wuhan, and draw up a government resolution to minimize contact between Chinese and Russian passengers.

site_title: From Larp to Nerf toys: Games come alive in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, a resurgence of interest in real-life gaming experiences has emerged, with various activities such as live-action role playing (Larp), Nerf battles, and escape rooms gaining popularity. Players pay to participate in these in-person games, offering an alternative to digital gaming. These experiences allow individuals to interact with others, move around, and engage in immersive gameplay, catering to those seeking a more social and interactive form of entertainment.

site_title: Founder of 1B2G Fine Vintage is in love with mid-century Danish Modern furniture
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Lynette Wong, founder of 1B2G Fine Vintage, has a passion for mid-century Danish Modern furniture, collecting pieces over the past 14 years. Wong invites visitors to sit on her chairs, showcasing her collection, which she believes she still has a long way to complete. Her love for the style is evident, and she continues to curate her collection, highlighting her dedication to her passion.

site_title: No need to kill your travel bug despite coronavirus outbreak, with the right precautions
summary: A travel expert suggests that despite the novel coronavirus outbreak, travelers can still plan their trips safely by adopting precautions such as practicing good etiquette on flights, e-registering with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. The Straits Times' travel editor Lee Siew Hua also discussed key travel trends for 2020, including affordable business class tickets and the use of "super apps" to maximize travel experiences. By taking these precautions and embracing these trends, travelers can minimize risks and make the most of their trips.

site_title: Wuhan virus: US and others tighten curbs on travel to China; death toll hits 213
summary: The US and other countries have tightened travel curbs on China, with the US warning Americans not to travel to the country due to the coronavirus outbreak. The death toll has risen to 213 in China, and several countries have reported cases of human-to-human transmission. Supply chain disruptions have also been reported, with companies such as Hyundai and Electrolux halting production. The World Health Organization has declared a global health emergency, but has not recommended curbs on travel or trade with China.

site_title: Wuhan virus: First Singaporean case confirmed; she was on Scoot flight from Wuhan
summary: A 47-year-old Singaporean woman, who was evacuated from Wuhan on January 30, has been confirmed as the first local case of the Wuhan virus. She was asymptomatic when she boarded a Scoot flight but developed a fever upon arrival. The Ministry of Health confirmed three more cases, bringing the total to 16, with the new cases being a 31-year-old male and a 38-year-old male. All three are in stable condition, and contact tracing is ongoing.

site_title: Warm weather with some showers expected in first two weeks of February
summary: Singapore can expect warm weather with occasional showers in the first two weeks of February, with temperatures ranging from 24-34°C. Thundery showers are predicted in the afternoon, mostly in the second week, due to the movement of the north-east monsoon rain band closer to the Equator. Rainfall for the first fortnight is forecast to be below normal, with January being the fourth warmest January since 1929, with a mean monthly temperature of 27.7°C.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Scoot to suspend all flights between Singapore and China from Feb 8
summary: Scoot suspends all flights between Singapore and mainland China from Feb 8, amid the growing severity of the Wuhan virus outbreak. The airline currently operates 100 weekly flights to 18 points in China and will reduce frequencies to eight cities before suspension. Affected customers will receive a refund. This move follows the Singapore Government's announcement to limit the spread of the virus, including barring travelers from mainland China who have been there in the past 14 days from entry or transit in Singapore.

site_title: EU warns UK there is no strength in 'splendid isolation'
summary: The European Union's top officials, including European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, EU Council President Charles Michel, and European Parliament speaker David Sassoli, warned the UK that it would lose benefits of close ties after Brexit. Von der Leyen stated that "strength does not lie in splendid isolation, but in our unique union," emphasizing the EU's global economic powerhouse status. The EU will present its negotiating position for a future trade deal with the UK, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson expected to reveal Britain's priorities next week.

site_title: Asian Insider, Jan 31: Can the world score wins in the battle to contain the Wuhan virus in the coming weeks?
summary: A world-renowned virus expert, Peter Piot, predicts that February will be pivotal in determining the success of the Wuhan virus containment efforts. The death toll has risen to 212 with almost 9,700 cases, and a relative of a patient infected with the virus beat up a doctor at a hospital in Wuhan. Meanwhile, Singapore is taking steps to combat fake news, and the country's government has debunked claims of Singaporeans contracting the virus. The WHO's Global Health Emergency declaration aims to curb cross-border infection and hasten response from countries.

site_title: Wuhan virus: City should have acted sooner, says Wuhan communist party chief
summary: Wuhan's Communist Party chief, Ma Guoqiang, stated that the city should have taken measures to contain the coronavirus outbreak sooner, which would have reduced its impact on China and the world. The outbreak, centered in Wuhan, has killed over 200 people in China and affected over 9,800 worldwide, surpassing the 2002-2003 SARS epidemic. The city's mayor and vice-mayor acknowledged the severity of the situation, citing inadequate supplies of masks and medical resources. The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency, prompting the US and other countries to tighten travel curbs.

site_title: 2 weeks' jail for man who attempted to record videos of women in toilet during funeral service
summary: A 23-year-old man in Singapore was sentenced to 2 weeks in jail for attempting to record videos of women using the toilet during a funeral service. Chua Jia Cheng had set up his phone in the bathroom, but was caught after two women found it. He initially denied placing the device there, but was later ordered to surrender himself. The court considered the severity of the offense and ultimately handed down a lenient sentence, with the prosecution considering an appeal. Chua was offered bail of $15,000.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Visitors with recent travel history to China not allowed to enter or transit in Singapore
summary: Singapore has introduced new measures to curb the spread of the Wuhan virus, effective February 1. All travelers arriving from mainland China in the past 14 days will be barred from entry or transit. Singaporeans, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders returning from China will be placed on a 14-day leave of absence. The Ministry of Health has confirmed the first Singaporean case, a 47-year-old woman who tested positive after arriving from Wuhan. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Italy declares emergency after first two cases confirmed
summary: Italy declared a state of emergency on January 31, 2020, after two Chinese tourists tested positive for the Wuhan virus in Rome. The couple, a 65-year-old woman and her 66-year-old husband, were being treated in isolation and 20 people who had come into contact with them were being held for observation. Italy stopped all flights to and from China, and €5 million was allocated to tackle the virus. The World Health Organization had declared the outbreak an international public health emergency earlier that day.

site_title: Tennis: Dominic Thiem shoots down young gun Alexander Zverev to reach Australian Open final
summary: Dominic Thiem overcame a sluggish start and a rain interruption to defeat Alexander Zverev 3-6 6-4 7-6(3) 7-6(4) in a thrilling Australian Open semi-final. The 26-year-old Austrian will face Novak Djokovic in the final, marking his first Grand Slam final appearance. Thiem credited his experience and composure for the win, saying Zverev was "unbelievable" and that he was "playing great tennis." The match was marked by drama, including a lighting failure and a code violation for Zverev, but Thiem's powerful play and clutch volleys sealed the win.

site_title: TCM practitioner couple suspended after causing 3rd-degree burns, illegal insertions of surgical threads
summary: A couple, Joseph Yap Kwok Ann and Xia Rong Rong, registered traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) practitioners, have been suspended for 30 months and nine months respectively for professional negligence and misconduct. They were found guilty of inserting surgical threads and performing moxibustion without proper supervision, resulting in a customer developing third-degree burns. The couple was also ordered to foot the bill for the inquiry and proceedings against them, and to provide written undertakings to ensure they would not commit similar breaches again. The TCM Practitioners Board emphasized the importance of safety in TCM practices.

site_title: Four special art exhibitions to be held in Singapore over next 4 years
summary: Singapore will host four international special art exhibitions over the next four years, featuring renowned artists such as Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, and Nam June Paik. The exhibitions are a collaboration between the Singapore Tourism Board and National Gallery Singapore, and will introduce global art movements and artistic pioneers to the city. The first exhibition, "Matisse & Picasso", opens in May 2020, while a Nam June Paik exhibition is scheduled for October 2021. Details of the remaining two exhibitions will be announced later.

site_title: Families of mentally incapacitated to get quicker access to emergency funds from Feb 7
summary: Families of mentally incapacitated individuals will have quicker access to emergency funds starting February 7. Under a joint initiative between the Family Justice Courts and DBS Bank, families can file applications at six selected POSB branches for immediate assistance with filing, with expedited verification and a one-time withdrawal of up to $5,000 within three days. This collaboration aims to make the process more convenient for distressed families, reducing the need to go to court, which previously took up to three months. Safeguards will be in place to ensure all relevant parties have given consent.

site_title: Wuhan virus: SAF working round the clock to ensure 5.2m masks to be given out are packed by Saturday
summary: Around 1,500 Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) servicemen are working round the clock to pack 5.2 million masks for distribution to Singapore households by Saturday. The masks will be packed in shifts of 450 people, each packing 200,000 packs of four masks each. The SAF is also assisting with contact tracing and manning thermal imagery machines at the airport to detect travellers with fever. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen assured that the SAF's operational readiness is not compromised despite the national effort.

site_title: Motor racing: Racing Point F1 team to become Aston Martin from 2021 after owner buys one-sixth stake
summary: Racing Point, a Formula One team, will become Aston Martin from 2021 after Canadian billionaire Lawrence Stroll bought a 16.7% stake in the British sports-car maker for £182 million. Stroll will join the board as executive chairman and pay for a 10-year deal. The team's title sponsorship with Red Bull will end after the current season, and a technology partnership will continue until the Aston Martin Valkyrie hypercar is delivered. The deal marks the team's fifth identity since its founding in 1991.

site_title: Wuhan virus: New precautionary measures at PAP meet-the-people sessions, including temperature checks
summary: Singapore has implemented new precautionary measures at People's Action Party (PAP) meet-the-people sessions due to the Wuhan coronavirus. Visitors will undergo temperature checks, hand sanitizing, and be asked about recent travel to China and symptoms. Those with recent travel to China, symptoms, or a temperature above 37.4°C will be asked to return home. PAP MPs and party activists are advised not to wear masks unless instructed to do so by the multi-ministry taskforce. Despite these measures, constituency events, including MPS, are expected to proceed as planned with minimal disruption.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Thailand confirms first human-to-human transmission
summary: Thailand has confirmed its first case of human-to-human transmission of the new coronavirus, a Thai taxi driver who contracted the virus without traveling to China. The driver's infection is believed to have occurred from a sick traveler from China. This marks a shift from the country's previous cases, which were all linked to Chinese tourists or Thais who visited China, where the virus originated.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Thousands on coronavirus lockdown at China-backed plant in Indonesia
summary: Thousands of workers at a Chinese-controlled industrial complex in Indonesia's Morowali Industrial Park on Sulawesi island have been quarantined due to fears of the spread of a deadly coronavirus strain. The complex, home to 5,000 guest workers from mainland China, has sealed off the site and banned employees and guests from overseas entering without permission. Indonesia has not reported any confirmed infections, but is preparing to evacuate over 240 nationals stranded in China. The lockdown comes amid an unprecedented lockdown in Wuhan, China's capital, where the outbreak originated in a market selling wild animals.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Britain reports first two cases of coronavirus
summary: Britain has reported its first two cases of coronavirus, with two patients from the same family in England testing positive for the virus. The patients, who had been staying at a hotel in York, are receiving specialist care and are not at risk to others. England's chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said the cases are likely to be minor, with a 2% mortality rate. The UK has raised its risk level to moderate and is advising those who have returned from China to self-isolate if they develop symptoms.

site_title: EU leaders remind Britain: No membership, no benefits
summary: EU leaders warned Britain on the eve of its exit that it cannot expect "the highest quality access to the single market" unless it adopts EU standards on key issues like environment, labor, and taxation. Without membership, Britain will not retain EU benefits and will be considered a third country, entering a 11-month transition period. The EU will insist on fair competition by aligning Britain with EU regulations, but London has indicated it will not be a "rule taker."

site_title: Software glitches that hit online Toto Quick Pick also affected iToto, some telephone 4D Quick Pick bets
summary: Singapore Pools has confirmed that software glitches affecting its online Toto Quick Pick system have also impacted some telephone 4D Quick Pick bets, excluding the number 49 in iToto bets and generating only unique digits for 4D Quick Pick Roll Bets. Affected customers will receive refunds and, in some cases, additional prize winnings. The Ministry of Home Affairs is investigating the errors, and Singapore Pools has committed to prioritizing customer interests and rectifying the issues.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Mask distribution to begin on Saturday at 200 RC centres, residents urged to check where and when
summary: Singapore to distribute over 5 million masks to local households, with collection starting on Feb 1 at 200 residents' committee (RC) centres, including Beach Road. The masks are being distributed as a contingency measure for those visiting a doctor while ill, and residents are urged to check where and when to collect. Collection timings will be staggered to prevent long queues, and information on collection times will be available on community notice boards, digital display panels, and constituency social media platforms.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Jay Chou postpones HK concerts to November, donates $590,000 to help fight virus
summary: Hong Kong singer Jay Chou has postponed his six concerts at Hong Kong Disneyland to November due to the Hong Kong protests and the Wuhan virus epidemic. The outdoor concerts, originally scheduled for December, will now take place in November, pending official announcement in June. Chou and his wife have donated $590,000 to aid the province of Hubei in fighting the virus.

site_title: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling, Sea founder Forrest Li join EDB board
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) has appointed two new members, Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling and Sea founder Forrest Li, to its 16-member board, effective February 1. The new additions aim to bring in fresh perspectives from the tech industry. Tan and Li will join representatives from traditional industries, including ExxonMobil and Procter & Gamble. The move is part of a leadership reshuffle, with existing members reappointed to their roles.

site_title: Coronavirus: Government looking at how best to help hospitality, tourism, retail and F&B sectors
summary: The Singapore government is studying ways to support the hospitality, tourism, retail, and food and beverage sectors affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said the sector will be impacted, with overall economic effects expected to be significant. While the virus is more transmissible than SARS, it appears less lethal. Wong also discussed the private residential property market, which remained resilient in 2019, and plans for the Greater Southern Waterfront development.

site_title: Pompeo pledges support for Ukraine as impeachment trial rumbles
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Ukraine on Jan 31, pledging Washington's support for the country amidst the US impeachment trial of President Donald Trump. Pompeo assured Ukraine of US backing in stopping Russia's aggression and restoring its sovereignty, following comments that appeared to downplay the country's importance to Americans. The visit comes as Trump's impeachment trial nears its end, with Ukraine counting on US diplomatic and military aid to combat Russian-backed fighters. Pompeo's visit aims to smooth relations between the two countries.

site_title: Prosecution asks for at least 30 weeks' jail for ex-Yale-NUS College student who filmed female housemates in shower
summary: A former Yale-NUS College student who filmed four female housemates showering on campus has pleaded guilty to eight counts of insulting a woman's modesty. The 26-year-old faces at least 30 weeks' jail, with an additional 16 similar charges to be considered during sentencing. The student had previously been dismissed from the college for breaching its code of conduct and posing a safety risk to the community. The offender had deleted the incriminating videos, but forensic examination retrieved them. He will be sentenced on February 7.

site_title: English to be used to teach maths, science again, says Malaysian PM Mahathir
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that English will be used to teach mathematics and science subjects in the country's education system. This decision comes after a previous attempt to phase out English instruction in these subjects was met with criticism and eventual abolition in 2012. Mahathir cited difficulties in students who studied science in Bahasa Malaysia later finding it hard to work where English was required, and stated that the use of English will promote mastery of the language in the education system.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Follow doctors' advice, don't let masks lull users into 'false sense of security', says PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong advises Singaporeans to follow doctors' advice on protecting themselves from the Wuhan virus, including not wearing masks unless unwell and practicing good hand hygiene. He assures there is a sufficient supply of masks in Singapore and urges individuals to stay vigilant and report any symptoms. Lee notes the virus is likely more infectious than SARS and may spread before symptoms appear, but its death rate is lower. The government is taking preventive steps, and Lee emphasizes the need for a collective effort to prevent community spread.

site_title: Weightlifting: Thai association's board resigns after fresh doping allegations
summary: Thailand's weightlifting board has resigned amid fresh doping allegations, following an undercover documentary claiming a "culture of corruption" within the sport. International Weightlifting Federation president Tamas Ajan has agreed to relinquish duties for 90 days as an independent investigation is carried out. The Thai Amateur Weightlifting Association admitted to a 2011 doping scandal, but denied any wrongdoing by its executive members. The scandal has tarnished Thailand's reputation in the sport, with the country previously banned from the Olympics due to positive drug tests among its athletes.

site_title: Spread of Wuhan coronavirus will further weigh on sluggish economy: Korea Herald
summary: South Korea's economy, which grew at the slowest pace in a decade last year, faces further challenges due to the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus. The virus's impact on exports, consumption, and industrial activity could delay a turnaround in Korea's exports and hit the local tourism sector, particularly from China, which accounts for a quarter of Korea's exports. Economists warn that the government's efforts to bolster the economy through fiscal spending may not be enough to counteract the negative economic impact of the epidemic.

site_title: 'Father of Cantopop' Sam Hui is a grandfather again
summary: Hong Kong singer-songwriter-actor Sam Hui, known as the "Father of Cantopop," has become a grandfather again. His son Scott Hui announced on Instagram that his wife Ida Lam gave birth to a daughter named Leah, while he and his wife have a 3-year-old son. The hospital has limited visitors due to the Wuhan virus outbreak, and Sam Hui's parents visited the new family. This marks the latest addition to Sam Hui's family, following his elder son Ryan and twin sons.

site_title: Asia to have largest GDP and what that will mean: Jakarta Post contributors
summary: By 2030, the Asia-Pacific region is expected to contribute 60% of global growth, with nearly 90% of the 2.4 billion new middle-class members entering the global economy. Asia's GDP is projected to surpass the world's by 2020, driven by growth in developing markets like China, India, and South-East Asia. This growth will require equitable development, addressing social and economic problems, and will lead to a bipolarization of consumption, where consumers demand premium and value-for-money goods and services. Governments and businesses must balance technological advancement, job creation, and talent reskilling with economic development and sustainability.

site_title: SIA-ANA pact will pave way for more flights, Japan destinations for Singapore consumers
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and All Nippon Airways (ANA) have signed a partnership pact, expected to boost the Singapore air hub and increase flight options to Japan for SIA consumers. The joint venture agreement, pending regulatory approval, will allow the airlines to pool resources, share routes, and coordinate networks. It is expected to lead to increased frequencies, travel conveniences, and revenue for both carriers. The partnership will also deepen the relationship between SIA and ANA, currently limited to a code-share agreement, and enhance connectivity between Singapore and Japan.

site_title: Golf: LPGA cancels China event in March over coronavirus concerns
summary: The LPGA has cancelled the 2020 Blue Bay LPGA event scheduled for March 5-8 on Hainan Island due to concerns over the new coronavirus and travel restrictions. The decision was made in conjunction with partners in China to prioritize health and safety. The cancellation is the latest move to slow the spread of the virus, which has resulted in 213 deaths and prompted extreme measures in Beijing, including quarantining over 50 million people. The event will be rescheduled for 2021.

site_title: New competition for redesign of Paya Lebar Air Base as a town of the future
summary: Singapore is launching a public competition to reimagine the future of the Paya Lebar Air Base site, set to relocate from 2030. The 800ha site will be redeveloped into a town, with three themes: Concept Master Plan, Transforming The Runway, and Rejuvenating Paya Lebar Airport. Participants can submit ideas until March 27, with prizes ranging from $3,000 to $5,000. The competition aims to create an attractive and sustainable township with inclusive public spaces, offering boundless opportunities for residents and visitors.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Seafood market may not be only source of novel coronavirus, says expert
summary: A Chinese pulmonary disease specialist, Professor Huang Chaolin, suggests that the seafood market in Wuhan may not be the only source of the novel coronavirus outbreak. According to a recent paper published in the Lancet, only 27 of the 41 initial cases had direct exposure to the market, while two patients admitted on Dec 10 had no exposure. No other sources have been discovered, but the expert believes the origin may be multi-source. The novel coronavirus has claimed 213 lives and infected 9,692 people nationwide in China as of Jan 30.

site_title: Future Forward Party dissolution risks widening generation gap in Thai politics
summary: Thailand's Future Forward Party, the country's second-largest opposition party, is set to dissolve, potentially widening the generation gap in Thai politics. The party's dissolution will likely exacerbate the divide between the young and the old, reversing the trend of the "red versus yellow" divide that saw a middle-class emergence against a conservative royalist establishment. This new fault line will pit the younger generation against the older, more conservative groups, threatening to destabilize the country's politics.

site_title: NBA: Toronto Raptors hold off Cleveland Cavaliers, extend win streak to nine games
summary: The Toronto Raptors extended their win streak to nine games with a 115-109 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. Kyle Lowry and Pascal Siakam combined for 42 points, with Lowry scoring 14 in the fourth quarter. The Raptors also completed a three-game sweep of the season series with the Cavaliers. The win marked the team's ninth straight, and they will look to continue their momentum in their next game.

site_title: Man in India shot dead at daughter's party after taking hostages
summary: A man in India took 23 children hostage at his daughter's birthday party, demanding 10 million rupees per child and the dropping of murder charges against him. Police shot and killed the man after he fired several rounds, injuring others. All children were rescued, but the man's wife was beaten to death by locals as she tried to escape. The man, Subhash Batham, was out on bail over the murder charge and had been celebrating his daughter's first birthday. All children were taken to the hospital for treatment.

site_title: Poly student given 18 months' probation after taking upskirt photos of 6 women
summary: A 19-year-old Nanyang Polytechnic student was sentenced to 18 months' probation for taking upskirt photos of six women at various locations, including MRT stations. Chiang Wei Sheng must perform 150 hours of community service, remain indoors from 10pm to 6am, and give up his mobile phone with camera functions. He pleaded guilty to three counts of insulting a woman's modesty and was suspended from school for two semesters. The court emphasized the importance of respecting others' personal space and boundaries.

site_title: New app to help match youth to mentors; 1,000 new volunteer mentors wanted
summary: A new app, WeConnect, was launched in Singapore to match youth to suitable mentors who can provide guidance on day-to-day challenges and life advice. The platform, an initiative by the Mentoring Alliance Singapore, aims to recruit 1,000 volunteer mentors to contribute 100,000 hours of mentoring. The alliance, which includes over 10 youth organizations, has already trained 300 mentors and connected 500 mentees. The app allows mentors and mentees to connect online and access resources, with the goal of empowering youth to achieve their goals through mentoring.

site_title: Wuhan virus: February will be pivotal in determining success of containment efforts, says expert
summary: The World Health Organization has declared the novel coronavirus outbreak a public health emergency of international concern, citing the potential for widespread spread. Experts say February will be crucial in determining the success of containment efforts, with the month potentially revealing the severity and virulence of the virus. The WHO has already reported 213 deaths, with preliminary data suggesting the Wuhan virus spreads more easily but is less deadly than SARS, which killed nearly 800 people worldwide. Countries, including Singapore, have implemented measures to curb the spread, including lockdowns, evacuations, and mask distributions.

site_title: French man killed in avalanche on Japan ski mountain
summary: A 38-year-old French man, Sylvain Lethier, died in an avalanche at the Tomamu ski resort in Hokkaido, Japan. He was part of a group of eight French citizens who ventured off the resort's ski courses into the untouched snow. Seven members of the group escaped on their own, but Lethier was found unconscious and in critical condition. He was confirmed dead after a rescue team located his body off the slopes. The incident occurred on Thursday afternoon, with the Hokkaido region known for its powdery snow.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Travellers breach coronavirus lockdown by taking bridge over Yangtze
summary: A virtual lockdown on vehicle traffic in China's Hubei province has not stopped people from crossing the Yangtze River by foot, raising doubts over the effectiveness of the measure. Despite the lockdown, people are leaving and entering Hubei province, with some even traveling to other cities in China. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a global emergency, and China has suspended trains, sealed off roads, and established checkpoints. The situation has led to deserted streets, closed tourist sites, and empty shops, with 42 confirmed cases of infection reported in the city of Jiujiang.

site_title: Wuhan virus: S'pore may announce new measures in wake of WHO global health emergency declaration, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore is closely monitoring the Wuhan virus outbreak, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stating that the situation is "dynamic" and "far from over." The World Health Organisation's declaration of a public health emergency of international concern has prompted the government to consider new measures. Lee emphasized the importance of individual responsibility, urging citizens to follow proper hygiene practices and report any symptoms to prevent community spread. He also condemned anti-Chinese sentiments, calling for a collaborative effort to combat the virus. The government is expected to announce new measures in response to the WHO's declaration.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Coronavirus spreading in Munich shows difficulty in halting new bug
summary: A business event in Munich triggered a cluster of coronavirus infections, with five employees from a German auto-parts supplier infected, including one from Shanghai who showed no symptoms during a trip. The infected colleague tested positive four days after returning to China, highlighting the difficulty in controlling the contagion using fever-screening at airports. The cases suggest asymptomatic individuals can transmit the virus, warranting a reassessment of transmission dynamics. All patients were isolated in a Munich infectious diseases unit.

site_title: RSN commissions final 3 of 8 littoral mission vessels to defend Singapore's waters
summary: The Republic of Singapore Navy has commissioned the final three of its eight littoral mission vessels, replacing the ageing Fearless-class patrol vessels. The new ships, RSS Fortitude, RSS Dauntless, and RSS Fearless, are designed to overcome manpower limitations and provide enhanced capabilities for maritime threats such as piracy and terrorist attacks. Commissioned by Manpower Minister Josephine Teo, the vessels are a testament to Singapore's determination to defend its way of life, with improved sensor technology and reduced maintenance workload. The RSN's ability to defend its waters and maintain sea lines of communication has been strengthened.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Malaysian ECRL rail project stops Chinese workers returning from Wuhan
summary: Malaysia's East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project has suspended Chinese workers returning from Wuhan due to the coronavirus outbreak. The decision, made by the project's owner, follows Malaysia's temporary travel ban on citizens from Wuhan and Hubei. At least eight visiting Chinese nationals in Malaysia have been infected with the virus, which has killed 213 people in China. The project will continue with local workers, and affected staff will retain their jobs and receive salaries.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers more upbeat but services sector turns bearish: Surveys
summary: Manufacturers in Singapore are more optimistic about business conditions in the first half of 2020, with 19% expecting improved conditions, outnumbering those who foresee worsening conditions. The electronics cluster is the most optimistic, citing the rollout of 5G technology and reduced US-China trade tensions. In contrast, the services sector has turned bearish, with 14% of firms expecting slower business and only 2% predicting an improved outlook.

site_title: Survey shows Democrats unsure if they can beat Trump in 2020 election
summary: A Pew Research Center poll found that 44% of Democrats believe their party's candidate can beat President Donald Trump in the 2020 election, compared to 79% of Republicans who think Trump will win. The poll, conducted ahead of the Iowa caucuses, shows Democrats are divided, with 48% saying they will vote for a Democrat, but only a quarter of them think a Democrat can win. Key candidates, including Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders, are vying for the party's nomination, but the poll highlights the challenges Democrats face in beating Trump.

site_title: Britain hails new start as it says farewell to EU
summary: Britain has officially left the European Union, becoming the first country to do so since 1973. The transition period, which will last until December 31, allows Britons to work and trade freely with EU nations. However, the UK will no longer be part of the bloc's institutions and must negotiate a new partnership with the EU. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised to lead the country to a "bright new future" but acknowledges the uncertainty that lies ahead. The country's division over Brexit remains, with some celebrating the end of EU integration and others fearing the consequences.

site_title: China to bring home overseas citizens from virus-hit province: Foreign ministry official
summary: China plans to send charter planes to bring back overseas citizens from virus-hit Hubei province, particularly Wuhan, as soon as possible due to "practical difficulties" they faced abroad. Two flights have already been dispatched to Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur to bring Wuhan citizens back to China. The move aims to address the concerns of Chinese citizens worldwide who have been affected by the deadly virus.

site_title: China trade body offering force majeure certificates to businesses hit by Wuhan virus outbreak
summary: China's China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) has announced that businesses affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak can apply for force majeure certificates to excuse non-performance on contracts. The certificates, recognized overseas, can help Chinese companies reduce losses due to severe impacts on goods and logistics. Businesses must submit proof of delays or cancellations in transportation and export cargo sales contracts to qualify. The move aims to safeguard the rights and interests of Chinese companies amidst the global emergency declared by the World Health Organization.

site_title: Do face masks help protect against Wuhan virus?
summary: A surge in demand for face masks has followed China's coronavirus outbreak, which has killed over 200 and infected more than 8,000. Experts say masks can slow disease spread by containing coughs and sneezes, but they dispute their effectiveness in blocking transmission. High-quality, tight-fitting respirators are considered more effective, but no 100% guarantee exists. Masks are still a sensible precaution until the virus's transmission is better understood. Medical experts emphasize good hygiene, including frequent handwashing and avoiding close contact with sick individuals.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Facebook sets out coronavirus misinformation battle plan
summary: Facebook is taking steps to combat the spread of misinformation about the Wuhan coronavirus, including removing fake claims and conspiracy theories that could cause harm. The company will expand its removal policy and conduct proactive sweeps to find and remove misleading content. Facebook will also provide free advertising credits to health organizations and partner with universities to inform forecasting models. The move is a significant step for a company that has faced criticism for not fact-checking political advertising.

site_title: US Democrats' bid for new impeachment witnesses likely to fall short; Trump slams trial in Iowa rally
summary: US Democrats' bid to call witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial appears to have fallen short after Republican Senator Lamar Alexander declared further evidence was unnecessary. With a vote of 51 needed to call witnesses, Democrats are unlikely to secure the necessary votes, potentially leading to Trump's acquittal as early as this weekend. Trump slammed the trial, calling it an effort to overthrow his 2016 election victory, and has been pressing for the unmasking of the whistleblower who sparked the impeachment inquiry.

site_title: Seungri indicted for allegedly procuring prostitutes for investors, overseas gambling
summary: Seungri, a former BigBang singer, has been indicted by the Seoul Central District Prosecutors Office for allegedly procuring prostitutes for investors from Japan, Taiwan, and Hong Kong between December 2015 and January 2016. He is also accused of gambling overseas with YG Entertainment founder Yang Hyun-suk, incurring losses of over $1 million. The indictment marks a significant step towards a trial, despite previous denials of an arrest warrant. Seungri's case is seen as less severe compared to that of two other singers, Jung Joon-young and Choi Jong-hoon, who received jail terms for gang-raping and other offenses.

site_title: Worker dies after crashing through ceiling at Tampines Mall
summary: A 26-year-old Indian national died after falling through a false ceiling at Tampines Mall in Singapore on January 25, 2020. He was cleaning the walkway above the atrium ceiling when he crashed through and landed on the third storey. The Ministry of Manpower is investigating the incident and has ordered a stop to all cleaning works above the atrium ceiling. This is the fourth workplace fatality in Singapore this year, following a spate of fatal accidents in November. The ministry has launched an enforcement blitz to target workplaces with hazards posing imminent danger to workers.

site_title: Battered at the polls, pro-Europe Britons gird for the next fight after Brexit
summary: Pro-Europeans in the UK, who outnumber those favoring Brexit, are looking for new outlets for their rage after Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party won the latest election. With Brexit set to become a reality on January 31, Remainers are rallying to preserve smooth trading ties with Europe and advocate for the rights of Europeans living in Britain. They are also pushing for the government to prioritize the threat of brutal factory closures and migrant crackdowns on the front pages of newspapers. Despite the Remain vote splintering into competing parties, pro-Europeans are organizing mass mobilizations, protests, and lobbying lawmakers to keep afloat their movement.

site_title: WHO declares Wuhan virus a 'global health emergency': What does that mean?
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the Wuhan coronavirus epidemic a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) on January 30, 2020, due to its rapid spread to 18 countries. The declaration aims to prevent cross-border disease spread while avoiding unnecessary trade and travel restrictions. It gives the WHO the ability to hasten global responses, provide temporary recommendations, and set global standards for practice. The move comes after mounting evidence of the virus's spread and follows a meeting of the WHO's Emergency Committee, which emphasized the need for international cooperation and solidarity to combat the outbreak.

site_title: 3 stations on Thomson-East Coast Line begin operations
summary: Singapore's Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) began operations on January 31, with three stations - Woodlands North, Woodlands, and Woodlands South - opening to passengers. The line, part of Singapore's sixth MRT line, aims to reduce travel time for commuters from Woodlands to the city center. Initially, the limited service will see trains arriving at nine-minute intervals, but free travel will be offered for three days to familiarize passengers with the line. The TEL is expected to be fully completed in 2024, with a total length of 43km and 32 stations.

site_title: USA Gymnastics offers $292 million settlement to Larry Nassar's victims
summary: USA Gymnastics has filed a plan to emerge from bankruptcy, offering a $292 million settlement to victims of former national team doctor Larry Nassar's abuse. The settlement includes a $215 million payment to the survivors, with additional funds from insurers for the Twistars gymnastics club where Nassar abused athletes. The plan also includes benchmarks to improve athlete safety and payments to other creditors. However, lawyers representing victims have criticized the offer, calling it "unworkable and unconscionable" and stating that victims may receive only $250,000 to $300,000.

site_title: Indonesian coal firm Resources Global makes year's first SGX debut above its IPO price
summary: Indonesian coal firm Resources Global Development (RGD) made its Singapore Exchange (SGX) debut on January 31, trading at $0.215, 5% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of $0.20. The company raised $1.6 million from the IPO, which will be used for general working capital purposes. RGD plans to expand its customer base and grow its operations, with a market capitalization of around $18 million. The firm's net profit for fiscal 2018 was $2.2 million, a 86.4% surge from the previous year.

site_title: Talking has stopped but uncertainty over Brexit remains
summary: The UK's Brexit process remains uncertain despite the UK officially leaving the European Union on January 31, 2020. The article's author, Richard Newlove, reflects on his personal experience of the Brexit process, having left and returned to Britain during this time. The author notes the repeated claims of a general election being held to determine the UK's path forward, but no such election occurred. The Brexit uncertainty persists, leaving the country's future relationship with the EU unresolved.

site_title: Coronavirus: Who needs to wear a mask and what's the proper way to wear it?
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong clarified that face masks are designed to prevent the wearer from spreading a virus to others, not the other way around. Masks are meant for people who are unwell and should not be worn by healthy individuals. To properly wear a mask, one should wash hands before touching, remove any tears or holes, and wear it with the metal band at the top and no gaps between the mask and face. Masks do not confer automatic protection and should be discarded after 24 hours or if wet or soiled.

site_title: Aliff Aziz beaten up in Geylang, former wife Bella Astillah willing to reconcile with him
summary: Actor-singer Aliff Aziz was beaten up in Geylang by a man who cornered him and punched and kicked him. Videos show the incident, which occurred on January 27, and come after a previous viral video of Aliff throwing a chair and exposing himself. His ex-wife, Bella Astillah, is willing to reconcile with him for the sake of their 3-year-old son, despite concerns from her family and fans. Bella believes that if Aliff loves and cares for their son, that's enough for her to forgive and forget.

site_title: Economist who counted $54.5 billion Sars cost sees bigger hit from Wuhan virus
summary: Economist Warwick McKibbin predicts the global cost of the coronavirus could be three or four times the 2003 Sars outbreak, estimated at $54.5 billion. The growing Chinese economy and the virus's contagious nature make the current crisis more severe. The impact will be felt mainly through changes in "human psychology," with panic being the biggest drain on the economy. Analysts, including Nomura International and Bloomberg, agree that China's growth could drop significantly, with Hong Kong, South Korea, and Vietnam likely to be the most affected.

site_title: Brexit propels EU into uncharted territory
summary: Britain's exit from the European Union poses significant challenges for the EU, including economic, political, and military implications. Brexit may hinder the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and defense cooperation, potentially shifting the focus towards London-Washington ties. The EU is now navigating uncharted territory, and the consequences of Brexit will likely be felt across various aspects of the Union's operations.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices slip in December as gloomy outlook weighs
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices declined 1.7% in December, marking a second consecutive drop, due to a gloomy economic outlook and a new coronavirus outbreak in China. The downtrend is expected to continue until the second quarter, with transaction volumes predicted to shrink. Despite a five-month decline in November, the market is still recovering from anti-government protests that began in June last year. Property agents expect prices to correct 10% from last year's peak, with the impact of the virus potentially reflecting in February.

site_title: Tennis: Young guns Dominic Thiem, Alexander Zverev shoot for first Australian Open final
summary: Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev will compete for the first Australian Open final after reaching the semifinals. Thiem, 26, defeated world No. 1 Rafael Nadal in three sets, while Zverev, 22, upset 2014 champion Stan Wawrinka. The winner will face Novak Djokovic, who ousted Roger Federer to reach his eighth Melbourne final. This matchup marks a significant upset for the established order, with the "Big Three" of Nadal, Federer, and Djokovic holding all but one of the last 14 Australian Open titles.

site_title: Wuhan virus: More infected in South Korea as cases reach 7
summary: South Korea reported one more case of the coronavirus, bringing the total to seven, as a 28-year-old man who had visited Wuhan, China, and returned on January 23, tested positive. The seventh confirmed case comes amid a global public health emergency declared by the World Health Organisation. The virus has spread to 16 countries, including Thailand, France, and the US, with over 8,100 confirmed cases in mainland China, and at least 213 deaths worldwide.

site_title: Asia shares struggle for footing after rough virus-scarred week
summary: Asian share markets struggled to regain footing on Friday as investors clung to hopes that China could contain the coronavirus. Despite a global emergency declaration by the World Health Organization, Chinese manufacturing activity came in as expected, and services firmed, providing some relief. However, the virus continues to spread, with China reporting 213 deaths and 1,982 new cases. Markets have taken a hit, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan down 0.4% for the week, and the US dollar strengthened against the euro. Safe-haven bonds and oil prices also rose, but the mood remains cautious.

site_title: Singapore's free trade deal with EU will apply to Britain during Brexit transition period: MTI
summary: Singapore's free trade deal with the EU will continue to apply to Britain during its 11-month Brexit transition period, which began on February 1, 2020. The agreement maintains trade continuity for Singapore companies doing business with the UK. Singapore and the UK are working on an agreement to maintain trade continuity after the transition period ends. The Singapore Business Federation expressed relief over the continuity of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, but noted the need for greater clarity on the UK's post-Brexit regulatory regime.

site_title: Australia on standby for fire threat as heat, winds return
summary: Australian authorities have declared a state of emergency in Canberra due to severe fire danger from heat and strong winds. Temperatures above 40 Celsius are expected, with an out-of-control fire in the area's south growing to 21,500ha. The crisis has sparked renewed calls for climate action, with scientists attributing the disaster to climate change. Meanwhile, neighboring New Zealand is also battling 25 fires and expects heatwave conditions over the weekend.

site_title: Coronavirus: Govt debunks fake news on Singaporeans contracting the virus and Singapore running out of masks
summary: The Singapore government has invoked the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) for the third and fourth time to correct false information about the Wuhan coronavirus. A website claimed five Singaporeans had contracted the virus without going to China, and opposition leader Lim Tean shared the article on Facebook. The government ordered corrections notices on the website, Lim, and a Facebook group, as well as instructed Facebook to correct a post falsely claiming Singapore had run out of face masks. The government also warned against spreading false information to prevent panic among Singaporeans.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson ordered to pay $468m over deceptive vaginal-mesh marketing
summary: Johnson & Johnson was ordered to pay $468 million (approximately $344 million) for misrepresenting the risks of vaginal-mesh implants to consumers in California. The company was accused of deceptively marketing its pelvic mesh products to doctors and consumers without fully disclosing risks, violating state consumer-protection laws. This is the first state to bring a claim against J&J to trial after thousands of lawsuits were filed over the products, which were intended to treat incontinence and organ sagging in women. J&J has vowed to appeal the ruling.

site_title: Wuhan virus: 852 students, 115 staff on leave of absence, says MOE
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) in Singapore has placed 852 students and 115 staff members on a 14-day leave of absence due to travel to China in the past two weeks. This measure aims to mitigate potential risks posed by the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak. Those who traveled to Hubei province will be issued with quarantine orders if deemed high-risk. Students on leave will be assigned home-based learning plans, and teachers will provide work from textbooks and workbooks. The MOE emphasizes the importance of staying vigilant and being socially responsible while allowing life to continue normally.

site_title: Too soon to tell economic impact of Wuhan virus on China: IMF chief
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Kristalina Georgieva stated that it's too early to gauge the economic impact of the Wuhan virus outbreak on China's economy, beyond the first three months of 2020. The outbreak has led to travel restrictions, factory shutdowns, and flight cancellations, prompting concerns about the economic hit. Georgieva cited the experience of the Sars epidemic in 2002-2003, which slowed growth but ultimately righted itself, but noted that the current outbreak occurs during a slowdown in China's economy due to trade tensions with the US.

site_title: Bank lending flat in December: MAS data
summary: Bank lending in Singapore remained flat in December, dipping 0.05% to $692.4 billion, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) data. This marks a reversal from the 0.5% increase in November. Business lending decreased 0.04% to $429.61 billion, while consumer lending edged down 0.1% to $262.79 billion. Housing loans also dropped 0.1% to $200.74 billion, primarily due to a decline in housing and bridging loans. This represents a 3.1% year-on-year increase in total borrowing.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Japan to enforce special measures for coronavirus from Feb 1
summary: Japan is moving up the date to February 1 for the coronavirus to be classified as a designated infectious disease, allowing for stricter measures to be enforced. The country has 14 confirmed cases, with two returning on a chartered flight from Wuhan. The government will refuse entry to anyone infected, consider stricter screening, and may pay for chartered flights out of Wuhan. The decision was made in response to the World Health Organization's declaration of a global emergency, and comes as the virus is believed to have originated in Wuhan, China.

site_title: Chan Ying Jian quits as BreadTalk CFO and CIO
summary: BreadTalk Group announced the resignation of Chief Financial Officer (CFO) and Chief Investment Officer (CIO) Chan Ying Jian, effective March 15. Chan, 37, will leave to pursue other career opportunities. Executive Chairman and Founder George Quek will oversee accounting, financial, and tax matters, assisted by the group financial controller and division financial controller. Chan's departure follows the recent departure of CEO Henry Chu for personal and health reasons, and comes after the company issued a profit guidance stating a net loss for fiscal 2019 due to weak bakery and food divisions.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China says it has confidence and capability to win war against coronavirus
summary: China has confidence and capability to win the war against the coronavirus, according to its foreign ministry spokesman, amid the WHO's declaration of the outbreak as a global emergency. The virus has killed at least 212 and infected over 8,000 globally, with the majority of cases in China. China will continue to work with the WHO and other countries to maintain public health security, while the WHO is concerned about the virus spreading to countries with weaker health systems, citing the need for international solidarity and responsible behavior.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Anger boils over in China as doctors plead for supplies
summary: China struggles to contain the rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak as medical supplies dwindle and hospitals plead for help. A relative of a patient infected with the virus beat up a doctor in Wuhan, highlighting growing frustration among medical staff. The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency, and China announced subsidies for front-line medical workers and plans to reopen factories to boost production of medical supplies. The death toll from the virus rose to 213, with 42 new deaths reported, and countries grappled with evacuating citizens from Wuhan and containing the outbreak.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China chides ‘mean’ US for travel warning as virus impact spreads
summary: The US has issued a travel warning to Americans not to travel to China due to the coronavirus epidemic, citing the risk of infection. China has responded sharply, calling the move "mean" and criticizing the US for contradicting the World Health Organisation's advice against travel restrictions. The warning has led to cancellations of flights, restrictions on travel to China, and a global economic impact, with major companies such as Hyundai Motor and Electrolux halting production due to supply disruptions. The WHO has designated the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern, but also urged countries to avoid travel restrictions.

site_title: Jeff Bezos just added $18 billion to his fortune in minutes after Amazon crushed in earnings update
summary: Jeff Bezos' net worth surged to approximately $129.5 billion after Amazon's 12% stock price increase in extended trading, adding $13.2 billion to his fortune in about 15 minutes. The company's fourth-quarter results exceeded Wall Street estimates, with a 21% revenue growth and a record 150 million paid Prime members worldwide. Amazon's cloud division saw a nearly $10 billion revenue increase, while the company expands globally with 23% more full-time employees.

site_title: China's factories were flatlining even before Wuhan virus outbreak worsened
summary: China's manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) dropped to 50 in January, signaling factories were flatlining before the Wuhan virus outbreak worsened. The non-manufacturing gauge was 54.1, compared to 53.5 the previous month. The outbreak, which originated in Wuhan, has further weakened domestic demand, with economists expecting a big plunge in PMIs in February and March. Forecasts for GDP growth have been revised down, with some predicting growth could slow to 4% in the first quarter and 5% for the full year.

site_title: Wuhan virus: SIA, SilkAir and Scoot slash flights to China
summary: Singapore Airlines' budget carrier Scoot and parent airline Singapore Airlines (SIA) will reduce flights to mainland China due to the growing Wuhan virus outbreak. Scoot will suspend flights to 11 cities and reduce frequencies to eight others, while SIA will also reduce capacity on selected routes. Affected customers will receive refunds and rebooking options. The moves come as other airlines, including British Airways and United Airlines, suspend flights to China due to safety concerns.

site_title: Hyflux hires Clifford Chance, Cavenagh Law as legal advisers after WongPartnership opts out
summary: Hyflux, a distressed water treatment firm, has appointed Clifford Chance and Cavenagh Law as its new legal advisers after WongPartnership, its original legal team, opted out due to a loss of confidence. The move comes as Hyflux struggles to secure a rescue plan, with a one-week adjournment granted at a High Court hearing. Middle Eastern utility provider Utico has offered a $400 million rescue package, but Hyflux must secure creditor support. A rival suitor, Aqua Munda, has also made an offer to Hyflux's noteholders and unsecured creditors.

site_title: Singapore stock watch: SIA, BreadTalk, Olam, ComfortDelGro, AA Reit, OUE C-Reit
summary: Singapore stocks were affected by the Wuhan virus outbreak, with SIA reducing capacity on select routes to Greater China, causing its shares to decline 0.4% to $8.54. BreadTalk's shares fell 2.6% to $0.57 after CFO and CIO Chan Ying Jian's resignation. Olam International's shares remained flat at $1.80, while ComfortDelGro's shares declined 0.9% to $2.17 due to Chinese operations suspension. Reits AA Reit and OUE C-Reit posted steady distributions, with AA Reit's DPU unchanged and OUE C-Reit's rising 12%.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Tourism businesses worldwide brace for a hit worse than Sars
summary: A global tourism crisis is unfolding due to China's Wuhan viral outbreak, with hotels, luxury shops, and attractions worldwide bracing for weeks of plummeting spending. Chinese tourists, accounting for 30% of global travel retail sales, are being restricted from traveling abroad, affecting industries such as duty-free shopping, casinos, and cruises. The virus is expected to have a greater impact than the 2003 Sars outbreak, with potential losses estimated in the billions. Several countries, including Hong Kong, Macau, and South Korea, are tightening border controls, and some have already seen significant declines in tourism revenue.

site_title: Pompeo warns of Huawei risk, calls China's ruling party 'central threat of our times'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has declared the Chinese Communist Party "the central threat of our times," criticizing the Chinese system, not just a single company like Huawei. Despite this, Pompeo sought to reassure British officials that the US and Britain will maintain a strong bond. The US has been pressuring European countries to ban Huawei equipment from new 5G networks, but Britain allowed Huawei to play a limited role in its 5G systems. Pompeo warned that allowing Chinese equipment in US systems poses a risk to national security.

site_title: Filipino church leaders nabbed in US over fraud, sham marriages
summary: Three leaders of the Philippine-based Kingdom of Jesus Christ were arrested in the US on charges of running a human trafficking ring and a fraudulent charity. The church, with over 7 million followers, allegedly arranged 82 sham marriages in the US over 20 years, forcing victims to collect donations and meet fundraising quotas. The three leaders, Guia Cabactulan, Marissa Duenas, and Amanda Estopare, were charged with immigration fraud and conspiracy, with penalties of up to five years in prison.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China's death toll rises to 213, total confirmed cases hit 9,692
summary: China's death toll from the novel coronavirus rose to 213, with a total of 9,692 confirmed cases as of January 31, 2020. The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the outbreak a global health emergency, citing its spread to nearly 100 cases in other countries. Despite criticism for a lack of transparency, the WHO praised China's efforts to contain the outbreak, and urged caution against unfounded rumors. International solidarity is being called for, with some airlines suspending flights to China in response to the declaration.

site_title: Charter flight carrying South Koreans from Wuhan arrives home; Europeans evacuated from virus-hit city
summary: A charter flight carrying 368 South Koreans from Wuhan arrived at Gimpo International Airport in South Korea on January 31, 2020, after a half-day delay due to Chinese approval for only one flight. The evacuees, who had no symptoms before departure, will be isolated for at least two weeks at two facilities in Asan and Jincheon. The plan was met with backlash from nearby residents, while other countries, including France, Britain, and the US, have also evacuated citizens from Wuhan. The World Health Organisation declared a global emergency over the virus.

site_title: As Britain exits EU, the future is far from clear
summary: Britain is set to officially exit the European Union at 11pm GMT tonight, marking the end of its three-year withdrawal process. The UK's departure has left both Britain and the rest of the EU without a clear understanding of the future relationship, leaving uncertainty about trade, immigration, and other aspects. This is the first time the EU has lost a major member state since its inception, with significant implications for European politics and economies. The outcome is seen as a major turning point in Europe's modern history.
