site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Jan 31
summary: The World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak in China a public health emergency of international concern, citing evidence of the virus spreading to 18 countries. Meanwhile, a German nurse was arrested on suspicion of poisoning newborn babies with morphine, and teen climate activist Greta Thunberg was nominated for the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize. The sun's surface has been revealed in the closest detail yet through a new telescope in Hawaii, and Formula One driver Lewis Hamilton is yet to start contract negotiations with Mercedes, despite reports of wage demands.

site_title: Facebook agrees to pay $750m to settle biometric data case
summary: Facebook has agreed to pay $750 million to settle a biometric data case, one of the largest consumer privacy settlements in US history. The company collected user biometric data without consent in Illinois, violating state law. The settlement avoids a potential trial that could have exposed Facebook to billions of dollars in damages. This is one of the largest consumer privacy settlements, surpassing previous payouts of over $10 million.

site_title: US stocks end higher as markets monitor virus
summary: US stocks ended higher on January 30, advancing after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus an international emergency. Despite concerns, the WHO did not recommend restrictions on people and goods, reducing fears of widespread lockdowns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 advanced 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.3%. Individual companies saw varied results, with Tesla surging 10.3% on strong earnings, while Facebook and Altria fell due to disappointing forecasts and write-downs.

site_title: Basketball: Kobe Bryant death has Jennifer Lopez and Shakira planning Super Bowl message
summary: Pop superstars Jennifer Lopez and Shakira plan to use their Super Bowl halftime show to convey a message of appreciation for life's fragility and the importance of living intensely, following the death of Kobe Bryant in a helicopter crash. The 12-minute show will celebrate life, diversity, and unity, with the duo promising a fun and power-packed performance. The event aims to promote a message of love, support, and empowerment, particularly for young Latino girls, as the two women take the stage for the first time.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Pilots sue American Airlines to halt China flights
summary: US pilots have sued American Airlines to halt flights to China amid the coronavirus outbreak, citing "serious, and in many ways still unknown, health threats" posed by the virus. The Allied Pilots Association filed a lawsuit in Texas, seeking a temporary restraining order to immediately halt the carrier's US-China service. American Airlines has announced flight cancellations from February 9 to March 27, affecting only its service from Los Angeles. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a global health emergency, but has not recommended travel or trade restrictions.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Italy confirms two cases, stops air traffic with China
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte announced that two coronavirus patients are in isolation in a Rome hospital, and all flights to and from China have been halted. The patients, who are Chinese tourists, were taken to the hospital as a precautionary measure after displaying symptoms. Italy is the first European Union country to take this measure, with Conte assuring the public there's no reason to panic and the country is well-prepared to cope with the emergency. The World Health Organisation has declared the outbreak an international emergency.

site_title: Wuhan virus: WHO panel meets to decide on declaring international emergency
summary: A World Health Organisation (WHO) panel met to assess the new coronavirus, which has killed 170 people and spread to 16 countries. The panel will decide whether the spread constitutes an international emergency, a rare declaration that would include recommendations to prevent or reduce cross-border spread while avoiding unnecessary interference with trade and travel. The WHO director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, will make the final call, and a declaration could include temporary recommendations for national health authorities worldwide and potential travel or trade restrictions.

site_title: Basketball: NBA All-Star game format to honour Kobe Bryant
summary: The NBA has announced a new format for the 69th All-Star Game in February, honoring the late Kobe Bryant. The game will feature four mini-games, each with a charity component, and an untimed final period with a target score. The target score will be set at the number of points scored by the leading team in the first three quarters plus Kobe's jersey number, 24. The game will take place on February 16 in Chicago and will include multiple tributes to Bryant, who died in a helicopter crash on January 26, along with his daughter Gianna and seven others.

site_title: US writer seeks Trump's DNA to bolster rape allegation
summary: A US writer, E. Jean Carroll, is seeking Donald Trump's DNA to verify an alleged rape in the 1990s. Carroll, 76, claims Trump assaulted her in a New York department store, and her lawyer has asked Trump to provide a DNA sample for comparison with genetic material found on her dress. Carroll's lawsuit, filed in November, claims Trump's denials damaged her reputation and career. Trump denies all allegations, calling them "totally lying." This is the 16th woman to accuse Trump of sexual misconduct.

site_title: US wants Israel to put off annexing in West Bank
summary: The US has urged Israel to wait until after its March 2 election before moving to annex West Bank settlements, according to White House senior adviser Jared Kushner. Kushner, architect of the US peace plan, expressed hope that Israel would delay the annexation process, which could be a first step towards formal annexation. The US plan, announced by President Donald Trump, has been rejected by Palestinians and faces opposition from many nations, including Singapore, which supports a negotiated two-state solution.

images.alt_text: White House senior adviser Jared Kushner, an architect of the US peace plan that envisages Israel and a future Palestinian state living alongside each other, says Washington wants the Israelis to wait till after their March 2 election before moving t

site_title: Happenings - Food
summary: No article provided. Please share the article content for a summary.

site_title: UK to be 'at front of the line' for new trade deal: Pompeo
summary: US Secretary of State Michael Pompeo promised the UK will be "at the front of the line" for a new trade deal after Brexit, a move seen as a boost to British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. This comes after a warning from former President Barack Obama that Britain would be at the back of the queue. The EU has given its official approval of Brexit, allowing the UK to leave the bloc today. Pompeo also addressed tensions over Huawei's role in Britain's 5G network, describing the Chinese Communist Party as the biggest threat of the current era.

site_title: White House cites secrecy laws, bars Bolton book release
summary: The White House has blocked the release of former national security adviser John Bolton's book, citing secrecy laws. The National Security Council deemed the book, "The Room Where It Happened," to contain "significant amounts of classified information," including TOP SECRET-level material. Bolton's book reportedly corroborates impeachment charges against President Trump, describing a personal conversation in August linking military aid to Ukraine investigations. The Senate is now considering a subpoena for Bolton, as Democrats push for more information on Trump's dealings with Ukraine. The White House is seeking the deletion of classified information from the book.

images.alt_text: Mr John Bolton's book contains "significant amounts of classified information", according to the National Security Council.

site_title: Dominant Novak Djokovic subdues Roger Federer for shot at 8th Australian Open title
summary: Novak Djokovic defeated Roger Federer in the Australian Open semi-finals, 6-4, 7-6(10-5). Despite Federer's strong start, Djokovic recovered to win in straight sets. Federer led 4-1 and 5-3 in the first set, but lost it in a tiebreaker. Djokovic, the seven-time champion, advances to his eighth Australian Open title.

images.alt_text: World No. 3 Roger Federer hitting a volley against defending champion Novak Djokovic. The Swiss led 4-1 and 5-3 in the first set but lost it in a tiebreaker. PHOTOS: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

site_title: Wuhan virus: China prepares for spike in infections during travel crunch
summary: China prepares for a potential spike in Wuhan virus infections as millions return to cities after the Chinese New Year break. Fever screenings and on-site quarantine facilities have been set up to curb the spread of the virus. Despite improved testing, hospitals in Hubei province face a shortage of medical supplies, and some medical workers have resorted to using makeshift gear. China, the world's largest producer and exporter of face masks, expects production to resume to normal levels by Monday.

images.alt_text: Workers disinfecting an area in Wuhan, Hubei province, on Wednesday. The public transport authorities have set up a system to deal with the spread of the virus amid the upcoming travel crunch after the week-long break.

site_title: Shot fired in New Delhi protest, student injured
summary: A protest in New Delhi against India's new citizenship law turned violent when an unidentified man fired at protesters, injuring a student. The incident occurred near Jamia Millia Islamia University, where hundreds had gathered. Witnesses reported the man brandishing a gun and shouting slogans against protesters before firing. Police detained the suspect but provided no details. The Citizenship Amendment Act has sparked widespread protests, with many accusing the government of discriminating against Muslims and violating India's secular Constitution.

images.alt_text: Above: An unidentified man brandishing a gun during a protest against a new citizenship law outside the Jamia Millia Islamia University in New Delhi yesterday. The shot injured a student (left), who is being helped by others. PHOTOS: REUTERS

site_title: Wuhan virus claims nearly 40 more lives in a day
summary: The death toll from the Wuhan epidemic rose to 170, with over 7,700 infected in China, as the coronavirus continued to spread globally. Experts warn that the virus is spreading aggressively, even during incubation periods, and potentially spreading from person to person. The World Health Organisation is considering declaring a global health emergency, citing the potential for a larger outbreak, with new cases reported in the Philippines, India, Finland, and the UAE, in addition to Japan discovering infected citizens on an evacuation flight.

site_title: 'They can chase their dreams': Dhaka offers education to Rohingya kids
summary: Bangladesh has announced plans to provide formal education to Rohingya children, who fled to the country in 2017, until the age of 14 and training thereafter. The move is seen as a significant step towards helping the nearly half a million effectively stateless children in the country's refugee camps. Officials say the decision will help prevent a "lost generation" and provide a new life for Rohingya children, who have already lost two academic years due to unstructured learning and playtime in international NGOs' operated learning centers.

images.alt_text: Yasmin, a Rohingya girl, helping her younger sister to study in the Leda refugee camp in Teknaf, Bangladesh, in this file photo from March 5 last year. Officials say Dhaka's move will provide schooling for Rohingya children till the age of 14 and tra

summary: No content provided for the article.

site_title: Businesses worldwide feel pain of dependence on China amid outbreak of Wuhan virus
summary: Businesses worldwide are feeling the impact of China's dependence on the country amid the Wuhan virus outbreak. Major companies such as Apple, Ikea, and Starbucks are taking measures to mitigate losses, including rerouting supply chains, closing stores, and paying staff to stay home. The financial blow from the outbreak is expected to be significant, highlighting the global reliance on China's economy. The situation is expected to continue affecting businesses and the global economy in the coming days. China's dependence on international trade is being severely tested by the outbreak.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Fears over outbreak further strain ties between Hong Kong government and residents
summary: Fears over the Wuhan virus outbreak are straining ties between the Hong Kong government and residents, with trade unions threatening strikes to pressure the government into shutting all borders with mainland China. The government has implemented measures to contain the spread, including suspending cross-border rail routes and halving flights to 24 mainland cities. Residents are hoarding supplies, including masks and food, amid concerns about the virus. Experts warn that the outbreak will further erode public confidence in the government and may lead to long-term economic and social consequences.

images.alt_text: People queueing to purchase protective masks in Hong Kong yesterday. Concerns about the virus prompted shoppers to sweep not just surgical masks, disinfectant wipes and hand sanitisers off the shelves, but also instant noodles and frozen food as peop

site_title: In Brief: Philippines reports its first patient
summary: The Philippines reported its first case of the Wuhan virus, a 38-year-old Chinese woman who arrived on January 21 from China's Wuhan city. South Korea also reported its first local case of human-to-human transmission of the virus. India confirmed its first case, a woman from Wuhan University in China, and Thailand denied Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha had the coronavirus. A cruise ship in Italy was placed on lockdown over two suspected cases, and Russia closed its border with China to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Republicans hopeful Senate will acquit Trump as early as today
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment trial in the Senate appears to be nearing its end, with Republicans hopeful for an acquittal as early as today. Despite Democrats' efforts to persuade at least four Republican senators to support witnesses, their push seems to be flagging. Trump's lawyer Alan Dershowitz defended presidential power, sparking astonishment among Democrats. Senate Republicans, including John Barrasso, predicted a similar outcome, citing "momentum" in favor of final judgment on Friday. The trial's outcome could have significant implications for the 2024 presidential election.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China to send chartered flights to bring Wuhan residents home
summary: China has approved chartered flights to bring Wuhan residents home, with several flights already departing from destinations such as Thailand, Myanmar, Singapore, and Japan. Airlines are allowed to board healthy Wuhan residents, and countries like Australia, South Korea, and New Zealand will quarantine all evacuees upon arrival. The US and Japan plan voluntary isolation for shorter periods. Meanwhile, Indonesia prepares to evacuate its citizens, with the government working with Beijing authorities, and Britain is preparing to evacuate around 200 nationals, with passengers to be isolated for two weeks upon arrival.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Malaysia confirms eighth case of infection
summary: Malaysia has confirmed its eighth case of 2019-nCoV infection, bringing the total to eight, all of which are Chinese citizens. The latest case, a 49-year-old woman, is in stable condition after being admitted to an isolation ward. Fourteen passengers from Wuhan who arrived in Malaysia on a flight were barred from entering the country after being deemed to be at risk of infection. The lack of temperature screening at Johor's checkpoints has raised concerns among frequent travellers, who report that no checks are made at the Malaysian side, despite stringent measures in place at the Singaporean side.

images.alt_text: A couple wearing masks at a Kuala Lumpur restaurant. The latest case is a person who was in close contact with the seventh confirmed patient.

site_title: Apple, Broadcom ordered to pay $1.5b for infringing patents
summary: A California jury ordered Apple and Broadcom to pay $1.5 billion in damages for infringing patents on Wi-Fi technology. Apple must pay $837.8 million and Broadcom $270.2 million. The verdict is the sixth-largest patent verdict in history. Apple and Broadcom plan to appeal the decision, with Apple criticizing the damages calculation in patent cases. CalTech, which filed the lawsuit in 2016, is committed to protecting its intellectual property and expanding human knowledge. The verdict marks one of the largest against Apple in its history.

site_title: Wasteful City must learn: Guardiola
summary: Manchester City progressed to a third successive League Cup final after defeating Manchester United 3-2 on aggregate, despite being outpossessed 61% of the time. City's Pep Guardiola criticized his team for being wasteful in front of goal, saying they needed to be more clinical. The match marked a significant comeback for United, who were down 1-0 before Nemanja Matic's goal and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's sending off. The win has given United a boost ahead of the transfer deadline, with the signing of Bruno Fernandes expected to quiet fan dissatisfaction.

images.alt_text: United goalkeeper David de Gea saving City striker Sergio Aguero's diving header during their League Cup semi-final second-leg match. City took 13 shots on Wednesday, with man-of-the-match de Gea saving all four that were on target. PHOTO: EPA-EFE

site_title: Shows by Taeyeon, NCT Dream, postponed
summary: Taeyeon's concert in Singapore has been postponed due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. NCT Dream's concert was also postponed, with no new dates announced. Fans who purchased tickets will receive refunds through their original payment method. The decision comes amid concerns about coronavirus proliferation. This marks the second concert in Singapore to be postponed, following Hong Kong singer Miriam Yeung's cancellation on February 8. Several other concerts in the region have also been cancelled or postponed due to the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Singer Taeyeon's concert tomorrow has been postponed.

site_title: Samsung Electronics' Q4 net profit falls 38%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 38% drop in Q4 net profit to 5.23 trillion won, citing falling chip prices and weakening demand in key products. The company blames the decline in memory chip prices and display panels, and expects "weak sales" in the first quarter. Despite a strong quarter for mid-range A-series handsets, premium smartphone sales were hurt by competition from Apple. Samsung is pinning its hopes on increasing 5G adoption to drive sales, with a planned rollout of an "enhanced" 5G line-up.

site_title: Honestbee gets boost from key investor, makes offer to creditors
summary: Honestbee, a struggling retail startup, has secured support from key investor Brian Koo and his associates through an investment pact with FLK Holdings. The agreement, subject to several conditions, includes a scheme to pay creditors a mix of cash and equity. Approximately 800 creditors will receive three cents on the dollar in cash, while the remaining 97% will receive shares in a new Singapore-incorporated firm. Honestbee's total debt to creditors stands at around $230 million, and a court hearing on its tenancy is scheduled for the same day.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Little global consensus on managing Wuhan evacuees
summary: Japan is struggling to balance human rights with public health concerns as it manages evacuees from Wuhan. Two citizens initially refused to be screened for the new coronavirus, sparking a domestic backlash, before agreeing to tests. The US, Japan, and other countries have implemented varying measures, including voluntary quarantine, isolation, and mandatory testing, as global consensus on managing evacuees remains elusive. Experts debate whether asymptomatic individuals can still spread the virus, and the issue has raised concerns about the need to protect public health while respecting individual rights.

site_title: Airlines may face 'steep' profit drop from Wuhan virus fears: S&P
summary: Airlines may face a "steep" profit drop due to the global spread of the Wuhan coronavirus, similar to the risks faced during the Sars outbreak in 2003. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) notes that the industry has proven resilient to shocks, with air travel rebounding quickly after previous outbreaks. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific, and Japan Airlines have already suspended or cancelled flights to China, but Iata expects the impact to be temporary, with air travel volumes returning to pre-outbreak levels within six months.

site_title: Wuhan virus: How businesses respond is crucial: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore businesses can mitigate the economic impact of the Wuhan virus by making the right moves, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo. The government is monitoring the situation closely and has resources to help, with a priority to mitigate the fallout and support affected workers. Businesses can explore alternative opportunities, such as teleconferencing, and focus on training to adapt to the uncertainty. The government aims to remain open and competitive, and is prepared to respond to emerging unknowns.

site_title: Asian stocks fall on fears over Wuhan virus
summary: Asian stocks fell on January 30, 2020, due to concerns over the Wuhan virus. The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore dropped 0.37% to 3,170.68, while Taiwan's Taiex Index plummeted 5.8%. Chinese markets remain closed. Despite some gains in healthcare-related stocks, many medical penny plays lost value, and property trusts saw mixed results. Analysts are cautious about the virus's spread and potential mutations, but some investors remain optimistic about companies' prospects, such as Venture Corp and Starhill Global Reit.

site_title: Apple, Samsung tied for world's No. 1 smartphone seller in Q4
summary: Apple and Samsung are tied for the world's No. 1 smartphone seller in Q4, according to industry trackers. Apple's estimated iPhone shipments reached 70.7 million, while Samsung's were at 68.8 million. Canalys reported 78 million iPhones shipped, surpassing Samsung's 71 million. The close competition marks a shift from last year, when Huawei was expected to challenge Samsung. Apple's strong revenue and profit growth, driven by the iPhone and wearables, contrast with Samsung's decline in memory chip sales, which historically contributed to its profits.

site_title: Facebook warns revenue growth slowing
summary: Facebook reported its slowest-ever revenue growth for the fourth quarter at 25% and its chief financial officer cited a surge in quarterly expenses, disappointing Wall Street expectations. The company's business is maturing, with growth expected to slow further in the first quarter. Facebook's expenses increased 34% to $12.22 billion, surpassing analyst forecasts. The company also reached a $550 million settlement in an Illinois lawsuit over biometric data collection. Shares dropped 7.2% in extended trading, raising concerns that Facebook's days of astronomical growth are behind it.

images.alt_text: A Facebook stand at China International Import Expo in Shanghai in 2018. The American social media firm is now struggling to restore its pre-2018 growth momentum, when sales regularly grew more than 40 per cent.

site_title: Climate change could be cause of next financial crisis: Report
summary: A report by the Bank for International Settlements warns that climate change could be the cause of the next financial crisis due to its potential to cause massive economic dislocations. The report states that central bankers lack the tools to deal with the consequences of climate change, which could include devastating storms, rising sea levels, and other extreme weather events. This could lead to widespread economic disruption, potentially triggering a financial crisis. The report highlights the need for central bankers to develop new tools to address the economic impacts of climate change.

images.alt_text: Life goes on as usual for these people in a flooded street after heavy rain hit parts of Dili city in East Timor last week. A report issued last week by the Bank for International Settlements warned that central bankers lack the tools to deal with wh

site_title: Tesla extends profit run; Shanghai production delayed
summary: Tesla reported its second consecutive quarterly profit, with a net income of US$105 million in the fourth quarter. The electric carmaker's shares jumped 13% after hours, reaching a record high of over US$600. Despite a loss of US$862 million last year, Tesla is ahead of schedule on its latest model and expects to "comfortably exceed" 500,000 vehicle deliveries this year. However, the company's Shanghai factory is expected to be delayed by up to a week and a half due to the coronavirus shutdown. Tesla remains confident in its ability to remain profitable.

summary: A murder mystery play, "Prism of Truth," will be performed at Esplanade Annexe Studio, where the audience will vote on the outcome and decide the truth behind a character's death. The play explores the concept of truth in the modern world, featuring various characters and social media information. It runs from today until February 11.

site_title: On social media
summary: Actor Godfrey Gao, who died after collapsing during a Chinese sports reality show, was born in 1984 and had a younger brother Charles. On the fourth day of the Chinese New Year, Charles posted a heartfelt message about still grieving his loss, expressing feelings of betrayal and disappointment. Charles has vowed to move forward and start anew, but still holds onto sentimental memories of his brother.

site_title: Proposal to restructure electric transport firm BM Mobility
summary: Singapore-based electric transport company BM Mobility has received a proposal from investment firm Silk Routes Financials to restructure the group. Silk Routes Financials is offering up to $1 million in rescue funding to support the proposed restructuring, which could involve investing in the company or acquiring/disposing of assets. The proposal is non-binding except for confidentiality and exclusivity provisions. BM Mobility has agreed to exclusive talks with Silk Routes Financials for three months to finalize a definitive agreement, which may include court-ordered administration or judicial management to give the company temporary creditor protection.

site_title: Food Picks: Master Chef Cook-off at Shang Social Mrkt
summary: Shang Social Market is hosting a Master Chef Cook-off Chinese New Year Set Menu with Beng Hiang Restaurant, where diners can choose between two dishes and vote for their favorite to win $168 dining vouchers. The set menu is priced at $238 for four people and includes three other dishes. Meanwhile, Coca Singapore has launched a new broth inspired by fish noodle soup, and Nam Kee Pau is selling a limited-edition Abalone Pau until Feb 8.

site_title: Singapore firms in China hit by virus
summary: Singapore-listed companies in China are temporarily closing or reducing operations due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Micro-Mechanics has closed its Suzhou factory until Feb 10, while CapitaLand has closed six malls in China, including four in Wuhan. Other companies, such as Straco Corporation and Dasin Retail Trust, have also taken measures. ComfortDelGro Corp, which operates in nine Chinese cities, has closed a driving centre and reduced operating hours at several malls. The companies are providing staff and cabbies with masks and disinfectants, and have established contact-tracing systems.

site_title: New Barbie dolls celebrate diversity
summary: Mattel has released a new Barbie doll line featuring more diverse models, including a bald doll, one with a prosthetic limb, and a doll with vitiligo, a condition causing patches of skin to lose melanin. The line includes dolls with various skin tones, hair types, and body shapes, marking the company's "most diverse doll line" to date. This move aims to promote inclusivity and representation in toys, reflecting the diversity of the real world.

site_title: Consider beauty products for your intimate parts
summary: A beauty brand, Two L(i)ps, has launched an anniversary box of five vulva care products priced at $700. This comes as more women prioritize intimate care, driving innovation in treatments. Strip, a company, updates its treatments annually to deliver effective treatment efficacy, highlighting the growing demand for intimate care products.

images.alt_text: Like your face, your intimate parts could also do with some pampering, such as by using vulva care products from the Two L(i)ps range. This anniversary box of five products (left) by the brand is priced at $700.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors denies emissions test fraud
summary: Mitsubishi Motors denies equipping engines with "defeat devices" to cheat on emissions tests. German prosecutors raided the company's offices, suspecting 1.6-litre and 2.2-litre diesel engines were equipped with devices to make them appear less polluting. Mitsubishi claims the 1.6-litre engines were manufactured by PSA Group, and no Mitsubishi-made engines have a "defeat device". The company has been "fully disclosing" its engines and control systems to German authorities and denies any fraud. This comes as part of the ongoing "dieselgate" scandal that has affected several car companies.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi Motors' offices in Germany were raided by German prosecutors last week as part of a probe into suspected emissions cheating involving the carmaker's diesel vehicles with 1.6-litre and 2.2-litre engines.

site_title: Israeli drama shows become global hits
summary: Israeli drama series are gaining global recognition, with original works being exported to international platforms. Shows like "Our Boys," "Your Honour," and "On The Spectrum" have won awards and been ranked among the best foreign series of the past decade. The success is attributed to the universal appeal of stories about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the ultra-Orthodox community, as well as the authenticity and local perspective of the productions. Despite limited budgets, Israeli producers are leveraging online platforms to compete and create high-quality content, with many having to juggle multiple jobs to make ends meet.

images.alt_text: Hagai Levi is the co-creator of HBO's Our Boys, which is based on the murder of a 16-year-old Palestinian boy after the abduction and killing of three Israeli teenagers by Hamas.

site_title: Boy band iKON to carry on with album release
summary: K-pop boy band iKON will release their new album, i Decide, on February 6, despite leader B.I's departure due to a past drug scandal. The agency, YG Entertainment, has chosen not to rework the album, citing that the tracks are group efforts and that reworking would prolong the group's absence from the industry. The remaining six members released new photos from their music video, alleviating fans' concerns about the album's impact. YG Entertainment has urged fans to support the group's next phase, despite criticism for not monitoring its artists' activities.

site_title: Happenings - Arts
summary: A local art exhibition is set to open in the city, featuring works from renowned artists. The event, titled "Creative Expressions," will showcase a diverse range of art pieces, including paintings, sculptures, and installations. The exhibition is expected to draw in large crowds and provide a platform for artists to gain exposure. The event is being organized by the city's art council and is open to the public. The exhibition is scheduled to run for several weeks, offering attendees the opportunity to engage with the art and artists. Dates and times are available upon request.

site_title: Joanne Peh to remain in China with kids
summary: Actress Joanne Peh, 36, and her husband Qi Yuwu, 43, will spend Chinese New Year apart. Qi will return to Singapore while Joanne stays in Guangzhou with their two children due to personal matters. Joanne expressed her gratitude for being together despite the circumstances, but also acknowledged the uncertainty and fear surrounding the Wuhan virus. She urged those separated from loved ones to stay strong, be safe, and keep hope in their hearts.

images.alt_text: Joanne Peh's husband Qi Yuwu will head back to Singapore while she stays in Guangzhou.

site_title: Pushing the bar higher each time
summary: Bvlgari unveiled new iterations of its iconic Serpenti and Octo Finissimo collections at LVMH Watch Week in Dubai. Chief watch designer Fabrizio Buonamassa Stigliani led the updates, pushing the bar higher with each new release. The exact details of the updates are not specified in the article, but it mentions the release of new pieces as part of the two prominent collections.

site_title: Music Picks: Pentatonix - The World Tour Singapore
summary: Pentatonix, an American a cappella group, is set to perform in Singapore with their "The World Tour" concert on February 11 at The Star Theatre. Co-founder Scott Hoying promises a high-energy show with covers and original material. Meanwhile, Chinese singer-songwriter G.E.M. releases a new album, "City Zoo," featuring electropop tracks and collaborations with Eric Chou and MC HotDog. Taiwanese singer-songwriter Eric Chou also releases a new album, "When We Were Young," exploring urban themes and showcasing his smooth vocals.

site_title: Sweet discovery kicks off grooming chain
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean, Jasmine Yong, introduced body sugaring to the city-state in 2016, filling a grooming market gap. Her business, Sugar(ed), offers a simple sugar, lemon juice, and water concoction for clients, including 750+ first-time customers. Therapist Nurul Ashikin, who handles about 8 clients daily, is one of Sugar(ed)'s clients, showcasing the treatment's popularity. Yong's initiative has successfully launched a grooming chain in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Therapist Nurul Ashikin sees about eight clients a day and has handled more than 750 virgin Brazilians - what Sugar(ed) calls its first-time customers.

site_title: Klopp focused on getting Reds over finish line
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp focused on getting his team over the finish line, rather than making history, as the team took a step closer to the Premier League title with a 2-0 win at West Ham. Liverpool are now 19 points clear and have 23 wins from 24 games, with 14 games left to play. Klopp expressed concern about records, but his primary goal is to secure the title, which is within reach with just eight more wins needed.

site_title: Film Picks: Accept the call (M18)
summary: A documentary "Accept the Call" by Eunice Lau tells the story of a Somali immigrant's son, arrested by the FBI in a counterterrorism sting operation, and explores the roots of his radicalization. The film, which premiered at the Singapore International Film Festival, will be screened at The Projector in Singapore on February 1 and 9. In contrast, a comedy-drama "The Peanut Butter Falcon" and a war epic "1917" are also set to be screened, with the latter winning 10 Oscar nominations, including Best Picture and Best Director.

site_title: Nomination for Polanski's film sparks furore
summary: Roman Polanski's film "An Officer And A Spy" has sparked outrage after topping the nominations list for the French "Oscars", with many condemning the inclusion of Polanski, who has been wanted in the US for statutory rape since 1978. Feminists and critics have criticized the film academy for not taking a moral stance, with some calling for a protest outside the awards ceremony. Meanwhile, actress Adele Haenel, nominated for Best Actress, has spoken out about being sexually harassed as a child, highlighting the potential hypocrisy of honoring Polanski's film.

site_title: Hair Removal Pain-O-Meter
summary: The article discusses three hair removal methods: waxing, sugaring, and laser hair removal. Waxing is the most affordable option, but also the most painful, while sugaring is considered a more thorough and cleaner method. Intense Pulsed Light (IPL) and Advanced Fluorescence Technology (AFT) are alternatives to laser hair removal, offering more lasting results with fewer sessions. IPL and AFT can cause some discomfort, while laser hair removal is the most precise option, but also the most expensive. Average session costs range from $20 to over $300, depending on the method.

site_title: French designer Agnes b. loves art, dislikes fashion
summary: French designer Agnes b., known for her fashion brand, is opening her own art gallery, Fab, in Paris. The 78-year-old, who dislikes fashion, shares a passion for modern art and aims to bring together art, music, fashion, and publishing worlds with the local tech crowd and residents. Her gallery will feature her eclectic private collection of over 5,000 works and serve as a "factory of culture and social solidarity." Agnes b. also tackles social issues, including supporting liberal causes and advocating for the rights of forgotten workers, through her philanthropy and activism.

images.alt_text: French designer Agnes Trouble, known for her fashion brand Agnes b., at her Fab art gallery in Paris.

site_title: Golding injured doing own stunts in Snake Eyes
summary: Henry Golding performed his own stunts in the new G.I. Joe spin-off movie Snake Eyes, resulting in several injuries, including a torn hip and meniscus. Director Robert Schwentke aimed for raw action over computer-generated imagery, which Golding believes lends an authenticity to the film. Despite the physical demands, Golding felt it was necessary to bring a real tenacity to the character of Snake Eyes, which will be released in October. The movie also stars Andrew Koji and Samara Weaving.

images.alt_text: Henry Golding says doing his own stunts in Snake Eyes lends an authenticity that cannot be found in other G.I. Joe franchises.

site_title: Intimate business gains ground
summary: The intimate care industry is gaining ground in Singapore, driven by the introduction of novel methods such as sugaring. Local beauty chains and salons are expanding, catering to the growing demand for intimate hair removal services. Sugaring, a method using a sugar paste to remove hair from its root, is being offered by studios like Sugar(ed), which has treated over 3,000 women. The industry's growth is attributed to the increasing acceptance of intimate care services and the rise of online job opportunities, as seen in the career change of Ms. Nurul Ashikin from factory work to intimate care.

images.alt_text: Sugar(ed) founder Jasmine Yong doing a sugaring hair removal treatment. The studio specialises in sugaring, a method of hair removal that uses a ball of sugar paste rolled over the skin to remove hair from its root.

site_title: Sports World: Temperature screening at charity football game
summary: Temperature screening will be conducted at the entrance of Our Tampines Hub before the Chiam See Tong Sports Fund Charity Shield football match, with over 200 spectators expected to attend. The event aims to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission. Meanwhile, a Japanese academic predicts that Wuhan coronavirus vaccines will not be ready in time for the Tokyo Summer Olympics. In sports news, Damian Lillard led the Portland Trail Blazers to a 125-112 win over the Houston Rockets, and the team will face the grieving Lakers in Los Angeles.

site_title: Happenings - Films
summary: A new film, "The Turning," is set to be released. The horror film, directed by Floria Sigismondi, is based on the 1898 gothic novel "The Turn of the Screw" by Henry James. The movie features an all-star cast, including Mackenzie Davis, Finn Wolfhard, and Joel Edgerton. The story revolves around a young governess who is tasked with caring for two children at a remote estate, but soon discovers malevolent supernatural forces at work. The film is expected to be released in theaters in 2020.

site_title: Aspiring actresses testify at Weinstein rape trial
summary: Two aspiring actresses, Dawn Dunning and Tarale Wulff, testified at Harvey Weinstein's rape trial, describing how he sexually assaulted them in the early 2000s. Dunning said Weinstein suggested a threesome to advance her career, while Wulff claimed she was raped in his Manhattan loft after agreeing to discuss acting. Although Weinstein has not been charged, his alleged history of assaulting women can be used as evidence. Weinstein, 67, has pleaded not guilty to five felony counts, including rape and predatory sexual assault, stemming from allegations against two other women, Miriam Haley and Jessica Mann.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Signing up for a job that could put him at risk
summary: Freelance healthcare assistant Wilson Chan, 40, has signed up to work at Changi Airport, screening the temperatures of inbound travelers, despite the risks of being in contact with the Wuhan virus. This role puts him in close proximity to potential infected individuals, highlighting the challenges faced by those working on the front lines of the outbreak.

site_title: Reskilling efforts for electronics sector ramped up
summary: Singapore is ramping up reskilling efforts for the electronics sector, with the Workforce Singapore and industry stakeholders launching expanded retraining programs for workers and firms. The Professional Conversion Programme has already benefited 900 local professionals, and 1,000 more are expected to join over the next 2.5 years. The programs aim to equip workers with skills in areas like production, research, and development, and technical support. This move is seen as a way to help workers adapt to the changing industry landscape, driven by emerging technologies like the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, and autonomous vehicles.

images.alt_text: Mr Effandi Sajari has benefited from the Professional Conversion Programme. After 19 years in the power sector, he joined the semiconductor industry last year, and now earns about 10 per cent more.

site_title: New year, new win for Cherie Tan
summary: Cherie Tan, 31, was named Singapore Bowling Federation's Bowler of the Year for the fourth time, following her consistent achievements in 2019, including winning the Masters title at the World Bowling women's championships. Arianne Tay, 15, was named Young Bowler of the Year after winning the Kaohsiung International Open Bowling Championship and the World Junior Bowling Championships. Both athletes expressed gratitude for their support and vowed to continue working hard to improve their skills.

images.alt_text: Cherie Tan (right) and Arianne Tay are the Singapore Bowling Federation's Bowler of the Year and Young Bowler of the Year respectively after both athletes won multiple titles last year. PHOTO COURTESY OF ELDRIDGE CHANG

site_title: Cue sports: Evergreen Gilchrist never too old for gold, and glory
summary: Peter Gilchrist, a 51-year-old cue sports athlete, is a nominee for The Straits Times Athlete of the Year award. He has won four world titles in the last seven years, including the 2019 World Billiards Championship in Melbourne. Gilchrist attributes his success to dedication, with over 40,000 hours of practice, and a mentality shift, letting go of past losses. He aims to become the first cue sports athlete to win world titles across four decades and inspire the next generation to take up the sport, which he believes has the potential to grow in popularity.

images.alt_text: English billiards player Peter Gilchrist had a prolific 2019, winning the world championship title and events in four other countries to earn a nomination for The Straits Times Athlete of the Year award. ST PHOTO: ALPHONSUS CHERN

site_title: Paedophile who abused dozens while in Singapore gets 35 years' jail
summary: An Australian man, Boris Kunsevitsky, was sentenced to 35 years in jail for sexually abusing dozens of boys in South-east Asia, including Singapore, over 15 years. Kunsevitsky pleaded guilty to 59 charges involving child abuse and child pornography, targeting 47 victims, five of whom were in Singapore. The crimes took place between 2002 and 2008, with Kunsevitsky working in Singapore at the time. He will serve at least 28 years before being eligible for parole.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Singapore religious groups issue advisories to combat virus spread
summary: Religious groups in Singapore have issued advisories to combat the spread of the Wuhan virus. The Methodist Church suggested alternative greetings to minimize hand contact, while the Office of the Mufti urged Muslims to practice good hygiene and avoid public places if unwell. The Singapore Buddhist Federation canceled its annual Chinese New Year gathering as a precautionary measure. The groups also advised against spreading unverified news and avoiding unnecessary travel to affected areas, such as China.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Freelancers wanted to man temperature screening points
summary: Singapore is recruiting thousands of freelance healthcare workers to man temperature screening points at air, land, and sea checkpoints in response to the Wuhan virus. The measure aims to contain the spread of the virus, and recruitment firms are seeking individuals to perform temperature checks and administrative tasks. This decision was made following the government's decision to screen all inbound travellers. The recruitment drive is part of Singapore's efforts to prevent the virus from entering the country.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Each Singapore household to get 4 free masks for contingencies
summary: Singapore has announced that all 1.37 million households will receive four free surgical masks each to combat the Wuhan virus. The move aims to provide sufficient masks for those who need them, but authorities urge people to use them responsibly, only wearing them if they're unwell. The government has sourced five million masks and will distribute them progressively from February 2, with priority given to essential services and vulnerable individuals.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Authorities crack down on profiteering by mask sellers
summary: Authorities in Singapore are cracking down on profiteers selling face masks at inflated prices amid the Wuhan virus outbreak. The Government's Price Controller has issued a letter to a retailer, Deen Express, demanding information on its mask prices and profit margins. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has also sent letters to e-commerce platforms Lazada, Carousell, and Qoo10 to identify potential profiteers. The government urges consumers not to support profiteers, stating that there are enough supplies for Singaporeans, and the online marketplaces have pledged to cooperate and remove listings if necessary.

site_title: Bryant's widow 'devastated'
summary: Vanessa Bryant, 37, the widow of NBA legend Kobe Bryant, has broken her silence after the tragic helicopter crash that killed her, her 13-year-old daughter Gianna, and seven others. In an Instagram post, she expressed her pain and gratitude for the support, saying she is "devastated" by the sudden loss of her husband and daughter. The Los Angeles Lakers, who will play their first game since Bryant's death, have announced plans for a public memorial service, with Staples Centre and the LA Coliseum being considered venues. An investigation into the crash is ongoing, with a preliminary report expected within 10 days.

site_title: Skills training for workers who maintain SMRT trains
summary: SMRT trains workers will receive skills training under a three-year collaboration between SMRT, Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), and SkillsFuture Singapore. The memorandum of understanding aims to improve rail reliability and drive innovation across the land transport sector. The training will focus on enhancing operations and maintenance expertise, with SMRT providing support to identify skills gaps and recommend training. The program is part of a broader effort to build a pool of local talent for Singapore's growing rail industry, expected to reach 360km by 2030.

images.alt_text: The memorandum of understanding for the training programme was signed yesterday by (sitting, from left) SMRT Trains chief executive Lee Ling Wee; SkillsFuture Singapore deputy chief executive for industry Michael Fung Jin Lung; and Associate Professo

site_title: Employment growth slows slightly among Singapore residents
summary: Singapore's employment growth slowed slightly among residents, with 26,500 more residents in jobs, a 3% lower figure than 2018. Unemployment rates rose to 3.3% for Singaporeans, while 3.2% for citizens and permanent residents combined. Employment growth was better than expected, driven by strong growth in service industries. Foreign employment grew faster, with 28,700 new jobs. Retrenchments were slightly lower at 10,700, but the overall workforce saw a decline in manufacturing employment for the sixth year in a row.

images.alt_text: Retrenchments last year for the overall workforce were slightly lower at 10,700, compared with 10,730 in 2018. ST PHOTO: KELVIN CHNG

site_title: Universities to admit more based on aptitude: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore universities, including NUS, NTU, and SMU, will shift from largely grade-based admissions to more aptitude-based assessments, covering 50% of undergraduates. This move aims to reduce reliance on academic grades and consider other meritorious factors. The Education Minister, Ong Ye Kung, also announced shorter pathways for A-level students and workers to access polytechnic and ITE courses, with options for course exemptions and work experience-based admissions. The goal is to create a more flexible and porous education system with interconnected pathways.

site_title: Wuhan virus: 92 Singaporeans back from Wuhan, but some still there
summary: 92 Singaporeans have returned from Wuhan after being evacuated on a chartered Scoot flight, but some still remain stranded due to displaying symptoms of the novel coronavirus. The returned passengers underwent medical screening and will be quarantined for 14 days, while those with symptoms may need to stay in China. The Singapore government and Chinese authorities are in touch to ensure their welfare, with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressing appreciation for the government's assistance in facilitating their safe return.

images.alt_text: The crew of the chartered Scoot flight that evacuated Singaporeans from Wuhan arriving at Changi Airport yesterday. Scoot said surgical masks were given to all passengers, and the crew had to wear N95 masks and surgical gloves on board. Labour chief

The crew of the chartered Scoot flight that evacuated Singaporeans from Wuhan arriving at Changi Airport yesterday. Scoot said surgical masks were given to all passengers, and the crew had to wear N95 masks and surgical gloves on board. Labour chief

site_title: More Singapore residents working as freelancers
summary: Singapore residents increasingly turned to freelancing as a regular form of employment, with 211,000 residents in such jobs in 2019, up from 210,800 in 2018. This represents 8.8% of the resident workforce, down from 9.3% in 2018. Many freelancers, 19,600, were forced to take up the work due to job unavailability, while others did it as a side job. The most common freelance jobs were driving taxis and private-hire cars, and working as insurance agents.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Only two visitors per patient allowed at hospitals' general wards
summary: Hospitals in Singapore have implemented a two-visitor limit per patient at general wards due to the Wuhan coronavirus, a stricter rule than the previous four visitors allowed. The measure has been in place since January 25, when three cases of the infection were confirmed in Singapore, and is aimed at reducing patients' possible exposure. The restriction applies to 11 public and private hospitals, with some also barring young children and visitors with travel history to mainland China within 14 days.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Pofma exemptions lifted amid spread of fake news on outbreak
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) has lifted exemptions for several internet intermediaries, including search engines and social media platforms, to comply with general correction directions. The move aims to address the spread of misinformation about the Wuhan coronavirus. General correction directions require internet platforms to broadcast correction notices to all users, not just those who access false content. This is a critical measure to provide accurate information and prevent panic amid the outbreak, with the government working closely with technology companies to achieve this goal.

site_title: Thermal scanners, first-aid booths at Chingay Parade amid Wuhan virus
summary: The Chingay Parade in Singapore will proceed as planned despite the Wuhan virus outbreak, with enhanced safety measures in place. Six Chinese performers cleared by a doctor will participate, and thermal scanners will be used to monitor the temperatures of performers and spectators. Nine first-aid booths will be set up, and on-site medical personnel will be present. Organisers advise spectators to seek medical attention if they feel unwell and to rest at home if not feeling well.

site_title: 10 must-reads for today
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan assured that the opening of the first stage of the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) will proceed despite the Wuhan virus outbreak. The government also announced that all 1.3 million households in Singapore will receive four surgical masks each starting tomorrow. Employment growth in Singapore slowed slightly, while unemployment rates rose. In international news, three leaders of a megachurch in the Philippines were arrested in the US on charges of human trafficking and fraud, and Bangladesh will begin providing formal education to Rohingya children in its refugee camps.

site_title: Two taken to hospital after 8-vehicle pile-up on AYE
summary: Two motorcyclists, aged 28 and 31, were taken to hospital after an 8-vehicle accident on the Ayer Rajah Expressway. The accident involved six cars and two motorcycles, occurring after the Portsdown Avenue exit in the direction of the Central Expressway. Police were alerted at 9:45am and the two motorcyclists were conscious when hospitalised. The cause of the accident is currently under investigation.

images.alt_text: Two motorcyclists were taken to hospital after an eight-vehicle accident on the Ayer Rajah Expressway (AYE) yesterday morning. Six cars and two motorcycles were involved in the accident that took place after the expressway's Portsdown Avenue exit, in

site_title: Next 48 Hours
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Today's sports schedule includes various international basketball, football, golf, and tennis events. In basketball, the ABL features HK Eastern vs S'pore Slingers and Formosa Dreamers vs KL Dragons. In football, Spanish La Liga matches are scheduled, including Villarreal vs Osasuna, Granada vs Espanyol, and Real Madrid vs Atletico. The Australian Open continues with women's doubles and men's singles finals, while the European Tour's Saudi International and English Premier League matches are also on the agenda. Viewers can catch these events on Singtel TV and StarHub.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Bus, train services not affected by staff on leave of absence
summary: About two dozen front-line public transport workers in Singapore have taken a leave of absence to minimize the risk of spreading the Wuhan virus. The Land Transport Authority confirmed the move, stating it involved fewer than 30 workers. This measure aims to reduce the risk of transmission on public transport services, such as buses and trains, amid the growing concern over the virus.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Three more confirmed Wuhan virus cases in Singapore
summary: Three more people in Singapore have tested positive for the Wuhan virus, bringing the total number of cases to 13. All are Chinese nationals from Wuhan, with no evidence of community spread. The latest patients are in stable condition, staying in isolation rooms at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. None of the 10 previously announced cases are critically ill, and most are improving. 164 suspected cases have tested negative, with 49 pending test results, and 170 close contacts have been identified, with 135 quarantined or isolated.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Masks should be used only by those who are unwell
summary: Singaporean government leaders urge citizens to refrain from panic buying and hoarding face masks, citing sufficient supply if used responsibly. Masks are only needed by those who are unwell and need to see a doctor. Despite retailers limiting sales, over 5 million masks were sold out in hours, threatening sustainability. The government is sourcing new mask suppliers and ramping up supplies from traditional sources, advising households to keep 4 masks for family members who may fall ill. The government considers hoarding "selfish" and "not appropriate," emphasizing the need for collective action to protect the entire system.

site_title: Vivian visits Malaysia
summary: Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan made a one-day working visit to Malaysia, meeting with various Malaysian ministers, including Saifuddin Abdullah, Xavier Jayakumar, Azmin Ali, Anthony Loke, and Muhyiddin Yassin. The meetings focused on bilateral issues and strengthening ties between Singapore and Malaysia. The visit aimed to further improve relations between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan with his Malaysian counterpart Saifuddin Abdullah in Putrajaya yesterday.

site_title: Jail and cane for paedophile who raped 12-year-old sis
summary: A 22-year-old man was sentenced to 11.5 years' jail and seven strokes of the cane for raping his 12-year-old sister, who was first abused when she was five. The abuse began when he was 13 and continued until his arrest in 2017. The court heard the siblings' mother knew about the abuse but failed to protect her daughter, instead trying to hide the pregnancy and cover up the incidents. The girl underwent an abortion and the case was marked by allegations of perversion and abuse of trust.

site_title: Employment data points to drop in productivity growth last year
summary: Singapore's employment growth exceeded expectations last year, with a 1.6% increase in total employment excluding foreign domestic workers. However, preliminary GDP figures show a 0.7% expansion, indicating a possible decline in productivity. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo attributed this to firms holding onto workers for the long-term, while economists suggest uneven productivity growth across sectors, with some improvements in manufacturing and services. The conventional productivity measure may not accurately reflect Singapore's true productivity, as it is heavily influenced by the global business cycle.

site_title: Daddy's home
summary: A new study by the Institute of Policy Studies found that 21 stay-at-home fathers and 9 of their spouses shared economic and parenting reasons for their decision, rather than traditional gender norms. The study's author suggests policy recommendations, including increased paternity leave, changes to the Grandparent Caregiver Relief, and workplace support for stay-at-home fathers. The findings challenge the assumption that mothers have an advantage in parenting, and highlight the importance of government policy support and communications in reducing stigma and promoting equal parenting roles.

site_title: Need to change mindsets, says father
summary: Mr. Lee Kwong Luen, 49, has been a stay-at-home father for 11 years to care for his son, Jue Ming, with haemophilia B and mild autism. He faces stigma in an Asian culture where fathers are typically the primary breadwinners. Despite the challenges, Mr. Lee is advocating for a change in mindsets, recognizing the importance of stay-at-home fathers and the value of their contributions to family care. His experience highlights the need to challenge societal norms and promote greater acceptance of stay-at-home fathers.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee Kwong Luen became a stay-at-home dad 11 years ago to take care of his son, Jue Ming, who has haemophilia B, a rare disorder where his blood does not clot normally, as well as mild autism. Mr Lee said that "living in an Asian country, we are us

site_title: Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan and religious leaders tour new TEL station
summary: Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan visited the new Woodlands South MRT station, one of three opening stations of the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL), despite concerns over the Wuhan virus. The minister assured that safety tests were completed during the Chinese New Year period and all systems are go for the opening. The station, located near a mosque, church, and monastery, aims to reduce congestion and provide convenience to worshippers, addressing issues such as illegal parking and accessibility for elderly devotees and those attending night courses. The station opens today.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan with (front row, from left) Masjid Yusof Ishak chairman Mohd Ayub Johari, Pastor Ivan Ho of the Covenant Evangelical Free Church, BW Monastery resident monk Venerable Ben Si and other religious representatives yesterd

site_title: Tennis: Kenin plays Barty pooper
summary: Sofia Kenin stunned world No. 1 Ashleigh Barty in the Australian Open semi-finals, winning 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Kenin, the 21-year-old American, trailed 4-1 in their head-to-head but never wavered, eventually prevailing despite being down two set points. The victory sets up a final against Garbine Muguruza, who also overcame underdog status to reach the final, beating Simona Halep in a thrilling match. Kenin's win marked her first appearance in a Grand Slam semi-final and earned her a projected rise into the top 10.

site_title: Wuhan virus: France confirms sixth case of infection with coronavirus
summary: France has confirmed its sixth case of infection by the new coronavirus from China, according to a French health official. The cases were reported on consecutive days starting from Friday, with the first three confirmed on Friday, a fourth on Tuesday, a fifth on Wednesday, and the sixth on Thursday.

site_title: Ex-property agent pocketed over $132,000 of client's money
summary: A Singaporean property agent, Lim Yi Han, misappropriated over $132,000 from a client, Ms Sim Kheng, who was buying a condominium unit in 2015. Lim used the funds to renovate his home and buy items, and later defaulted on payments. The developer forfeited the property and $153,111.60 of the client's payment. Lim pleaded guilty to one count of criminal breach of trust and was sentenced to two years' jail. He had also made a voluntary compensation of $18,000.

site_title: UOB raises $1.8m for local charities
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) raised over $1.8 million for local charities, including The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, at its annual Chinese New Year fund-raiser in Singapore. The event featured a silent auction of a painting by Tan Rui Rong, which sold for $103,000. UOB matched its clients' donations dollar for dollar, up to $250,000, and also hosted art jamming sessions and an early reunion dinner for underprivileged families and senior citizens. The bank's Chinese New Year fund-raising series aims to support local charities and communities.

images.alt_text: More than $1.8 million was raised for local charities, including The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, by United Overseas Bank (UOB) Group Commercial Banking and more than 800 of its clients at an annual Chinese New Year fund-raiser held at The

site_title: Man fined for illegal activities on farm
summary: A Singapore man, Seo Chau Hian, was fined $7,000 for illegally renting out space on his farm, Malaysian Feedmills Farms, between 2017 and last year. He also allowed another company to store wood waste on the premises in 2018, breaching farm licensing conditions. A fire that took over 24 hours to extinguish broke out at the farm in 2018 due to a large pile of wood waste. Seo was also warned that unapproved activities on agricultural land can result in fines up to $10,000 or jail time for up to three years.

images.alt_text: Seo Chau Hian illegally rented out space on Malaysian Feedmills Farms and let another company store wood waste there. PHOTO: SINGAPORE FOOD AGENCY

site_title: Retro video games are the next hot collectible
summary: Retro video games are gaining popularity as a collectible item, with vintage games selling for millions of dollars. The market is driven by collectors seeking the next hot item, as seen with the surge in interest in factory-sealed video games over the past year. Companies are now targeting collectors from established markets, further fueling the trend. This shift is reminiscent of the current demand for vintage items like baseball cards and antique coins.

images.alt_text: Owner Josh Hamblin at his SideQuest Games store in Portland, Oregon.

site_title: Football: Messi on song as Barca ease into Copa quarters
summary: Barcelona secured a 5-0 win over Leganes in the Copa del Rey on January 30, advancing to the quarter-finals. Lionel Messi inspired the team, scoring a deflected third goal and rounding off the scoring in the final minute. Antoine Griezmann also scored, with Nelson Semedo providing the opening goal. The victory marked a strong performance by Barcelona, who will join Real Madrid, Villarreal, and others in the quarter-final draw to be held on Friday.

site_title: Wuhan virus: WHO declares China virus outbreak an international emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the coronavirus epidemic in China a public health emergency of international concern, citing evidence of the virus spreading to 18 countries. Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus made the announcement after a meeting of the WHO's Emergency Committee, emphasizing the potential for the virus to spread to countries with weaker health systems. The declaration triggers recommendations for national health authorities worldwide to prevent or reduce cross-border spread of disease while avoiding unnecessary interference with trade and travel.

site_title: Democrats, Republicans in high-stakes tussle over witnesses in Trump impeachment trial
summary: US senators engaged in a heated debate over witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial, with Democrats pushing for witnesses like former national security adviser John Bolton to shed more light on Trump's alleged abuse of power. Republicans, who control the Senate, argue that the trial could end as early as Friday with Trump's acquittal, potentially before all witnesses are called. The trial's outcome hinges on whether at least four Republican senators will join Democrats to secure a majority vote, with key undecided senators including Lisa Murkowski and Mitt Romney.

site_title: At least 20 women and children held hostage in north Indian village
summary: At least 20 women and children are being held hostage in a north Indian village by a man who had invited them to a birthday party. The man, serving a life sentence for murder, opened fire and injured two police officers and a villager. He is reportedly holding the children and women at gunpoint in his house. A team of counter-terrorism forces and local police are attempting to rescue the hostages. The motive behind the incident is unclear, and the number of women and children held hostage is not confirmed.

site_title: Wuhan virus: US sees first case of human-to-human infection
summary: US health officials confirmed the first case of human-to-human transmission of the 2019 novel coronavirus, a man in Illinois who contracted the illness from his wife. The man's condition is stable, but his underlying medical conditions have exacerbated his situation. This case brings the total number of confirmed US patients to six, with the first case being a woman who recently traveled to Wuhan, China. Despite the spread of the virus to over 15 countries, the overall risk to Americans remains low, and the pathogen is not spreading widely in communities.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Israel not accepting flights from China, El Al suspends route
summary: Israel's Health Ministry has banned flights from China due to the coronavirus outbreak, following the lead of other carriers. El Al Israel Airlines has suspended flights to Beijing until March 25. The Health Ministry also issued a directive advising travelers who visited China in the past 14 days to stay home for two weeks and return to work only after 15 days if no symptoms appear.

site_title: Jump in pound before Bank of England rate announcement prompts questions
summary: The pound jumped in value just before the Bank of England's interest rate announcement, prompting an investigation by the UK's Financial Conduct Authority. Sterling surged 0.5 cents to US$1.3075 in one minute before the decision, a move that surprised some traders. The BoE asked the FCA to investigate possible knowledge of the decision among market participants. Analysts say the move could be attributed to large buy orders, but others consider it suspicious, with some speculating it may have been a coordinated trade. The FCA is looking into the incident.

site_title: Football: Rojo joins Estudiantes on loan from Man United
summary: Argentine defender Marcos Rojo has rejoined his hometown club Estudiantes on a six-month loan deal from Manchester United. The 29-year-old, who has fallen down the pecking order at Old Trafford, will aim to gain vital game time ahead of the Copa America in June. Rojo, who has 18 months left on his contract with United, played for Estudiantes from 2008 to 2010 before moving to Spartak Moscow and Sporting Lisbon. His loan move is seen as a chance for him to regain form and be part of Argentina's Copa America squad.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton yet to open contract negotiations with Mercedes
summary: Formula One world champion Lewis Hamilton has denied reports that contract talks with Mercedes have stalled over wage demands. Despite speculation, Hamilton claims he has not spoken with team principal Toto Wolff about a contract extension, stating that "nothing is being negotiated currently." The 35-year-old has previously negotiated his own contracts, citing a desire to avoid rushing the process. Hamilton's future remains uncertain, with Ferrari and Red Bull reportedly considering him as a potential replacement for their drivers.

site_title: British man found guilty of trying to steal 800-year-old copy of Magna Carta from cathedral
summary: A British man, Mark Royden, 47, was found guilty of attempting to steal a 1215 original version of the Magna Carta from Salisbury Cathedral. He smashed the case with a hammer, believing the document was a fake, but was chased off by tourists and cornered by stonemasons. Royden has 23 previous convictions and was aided by a carer due to brain damage from a 1991 car accident. He faces an immediate sentence of custody.

site_title: From pitch to reality
summary: Freestyle footballer Valerie Su, 27, credits her double major degree in Business (Sports and Events Management and International Business) from James Cook University (JCU) for translating her passion into a business. Su initially studied biomedical sciences and worked in various jobs before realizing her passion for sports management. She then pursued her degree, which included a six-month internship with Paris Saint-Germain Football Asia Pacific. The degree equipped her with relevant skills, including conceptual skills for the fast-paced sports industry, allowing her to establish a freestyle football facility, Expy the Lab, in 2019.
