site_title: Medical emergency on Mars? AI may be able to help
summary: A US scientist, Kim Binsted, suggests that artificial intelligence can aid in medical emergencies on Mars, where communication delays can be up to 20 minutes. AI could potentially provide advice on treatment and predict mental health states, helping responders make informed decisions. Binsted, principal investigator of the Hawaii Space Exploration Analog and Simulation, sees AI's role in troubleshooting technical problems as a starting point for its use in space exploration. This could be a crucial factor in responding to medical emergencies on the distant planet.

images.alt_text: American scientist Kim Binsted, who is the principal investigator of the Hawaii Space Exploration Analog and Simulation, a long-duration Mars simulation habitat, says there are many ways artificial intelligence can play a role in space exploration, i

site_title: Mike Pompeo brushes off Huawei tensions to hand Britain Brexit trade boost
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed support for a "gold standard" free trade deal with Britain after Brexit, calling their special relationship "in a fantastic place." He assured Prime Minister Boris Johnson that the US would prioritize sealing a deal, despite tensions over issues like Huawei and the UK's digital tax on US tech giants. Pompeo said progress could be made by the end of the year, but acknowledged difficult issues, including agriculture and the UK's National Health Service.

site_title: Football: Bruno Fernandes hails Ronaldo influence in Manchester United move
summary: Bruno Fernandes has completed his move from Sporting Lisbon to Manchester United, signing a five-and-a-half year contract worth €55 million with an option to extend. The 25-year-old Portugal midfielder cited Cristiano Ronaldo's influence as the reason for his move, saying he was inspired by Ronaldo's time at United. Fernandes' arrival aims to address Manchester United's midfield woes, with the player boasting 63 goals in 137 appearances for Sporting. The transfer marks a significant boost to United's chances of a top-four finish and potential Europa League qualification.

site_title: Football: Spurs' Danny Rose joins Newcastle on loan
summary: Newcastle United has signed England left-back Danny Rose on a loan from Tottenham Hotspur until the end of the season. Rose, 29, joins the club as a replacement for injured players Jetro Willems and Paul Dummett. He expressed his excitement to play in front of Newcastle fans and repay manager Steve Bruce. Rose's long-term future at Spurs has been uncertain since Jose Mourinho's appointment in November, and his arrival is seen as a timely boost to the team. Rose is eligible to make his debut in Newcastle's league match against Norwich on Saturday.

site_title: Coronavirus: Chinese communities warn of Italy 'racism' over virus
summary: Chinese communities in Italy warned of "latent racism" against Chinese people due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing instances of bullying and discrimination. Italian newspapers reported cases of Chinese tourists being spat at, families being accused of carrying the disease, and mothers calling for Italian children to be kept away from Chinese classmates. Local health officials rejected these claims, stating there's no need to restrict the presence of Chinese children in schools. Italian-Chinese communities fear the outbreak is affecting tourism, worth 300 million euros a month.

site_title: Wuhan virus: 3 more confirmed cases in Singapore, bringing total to 13
summary: Three more Chinese nationals from Wuhan have tested positive for the Wuhan virus in Singapore, bringing the total to 13 confirmed cases. The new patients are in stable condition and being treated in isolation at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. There is no evidence of community spread in Singapore, and all 139 suspected cases have been tested, with 164 showing negative results and 49 test results pending.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Air France joins China exodus as virus unnerves cabin crew
summary: Air France joins other major airlines in suspending flights to mainland China due to the rapidly-spreading coronavirus, which has killed over 170 people. The airline cited health and safety concerns after cabin crew unions demanded an immediate halt to flights to Beijing and Shanghai. Other airlines, such as British Airways and Lufthansa, have also suspended flights to mainland China, with some carriers taking additional measures to reduce exposure, including wearing protective gear and shortening layovers. The decision follows growing pressure and concerns among airline staff.

site_title: Britain's press watchdog rejects Prince Harry's complaint over drugged wildlife article
summary: Britain's Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO) has rejected Prince Harry's complaint over a tabloid newspaper article alleging that wildlife in photos he posted on Instagram had been drugged and tied up. The article, published in the Mail on Sunday, claimed the photos were edited to conceal the use of tranquilizers and ropes. Prince Harry argued the article was inaccurate, stating his caption explained the animals' relocation as part of conservation efforts and the photo was edited for Instagram's formatting. IPSO's complaints committee sided with the paper, finding the article not misleading.

site_title: German nurse 'poisoned babies with morphine'
summary: A German nurse has been arrested on suspicion of poisoning five newborn babies with morphine, but the infants have survived. The nurse allegedly mixed breast milk with morphine in an oral syringe found in her locker at Ulm University Hospital. The babies developed breathing problems around Dec 20, but were saved due to immediate medical action. The nurse denies the allegations and faces five counts of attempted manslaughter and grievous bodily harm. An investigation found inconsistencies in the hospital's data, and the incident has raised concerns about hospital procedures and the use of morphine in infants.

site_title: New telescope reveals sun's surface in closest detail yet
summary: A new telescope installed on Haleakala volcano in Hawaii has captured the closest detail images of the sun's surface yet, revealing features as small as 30km across. The National Science Foundation's Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope features the world's largest solar 4m mirror and shows turbulent gas patterns, visible cell-like structures, and magnetic field markers. Studying the sun's activity can help scientists predict problems on Earth, including disruptions to satellites, GPS, and power grids. The telescope aims to improve understanding of space weather and forecast solar storms.

site_title: Wuhan virus: China sacks senior city health official unable to answer basic questions
summary: Chinese authorities have sacked the health chief of Huanggang city, Ms Tang Zhihong, after she failed to answer basic questions on state television about the city's response to the coronavirus outbreak. The city has reported almost 500 confirmed cases and 12 deaths. The government has promised to investigate and punish officials who slack off on the job. The move sparked widespread public anger, with the original story generating over half a million comments on Weibo in a few hours. Huanggang city remains largely shut off from the outside world to control the virus' spread.

site_title: US-Israeli woman pardoned by Putin flies home with Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu escorted 26-year-old Naama Issachar, a US-Israeli woman jailed for drug trafficking in Russia, back to Tel Aviv after she was pardoned by President Vladimir Putin. Issachar had been imprisoned for 10 months after being arrested at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport in April 2019. Putin's pardon came after Issachar submitted a request for clemency, and Netanyahu used the move as a publicity coup ahead of March 2 elections. The pardon was seen as a victory for Netanyahu, who had pledged to secure Issachar's release.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Only two visitors per patient allowed at hospitals; children discouraged from visiting
summary: Hospitals in Singapore have implemented a two-visitor limit per patient during visiting hours as a precautionary measure against the Wuhan coronavirus. The stricter rule, introduced since the Chinese New Year, replaces the previous four-visitor limit. At least four hospitals are also barring young children from visiting patients due to their lower immunity. Visitors are required to inform staff of any recent travel to mainland China and potential symptoms. The restrictions aim to reduce patients' exposure to the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Thailand arrests two for 'fake news' posts
summary: Thai authorities arrested two individuals for posting "fake news" about the coronavirus, with one sharing a misleading video clip and the other promoting false information about a case in a beachside city. The arrests come as Thailand has detected 14 cases, the second-highest number outside China, with 170 reported deaths since the outbreak began. The country's Digital Economy Minister warned Internet users to verify sources before sharing information, amid a surge in online misinformation. Thailand has established an anti-fake news centre to monitor and counter online misinformation.

site_title: Teen climate activist Greta Thunberg nominated for Nobel Peace Prize by Swedish MPs
summary: Teen climate activist Greta Thunberg has been nominated for the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize by two Swedish lawmakers for her efforts to raise awareness about the climate crisis and inspire global action. The nomination acknowledges her work as the leader of the "Fridays for Future" movement, which has mobilized millions of young people to demand climate action. The Norwegian Nobel Committee accepts nominations until February 1, and Thunberg's nomination is seen as a recognition of her impact in bringing the climate issue to the forefront of global politics.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Vietnam to stop issuing visas for Chinese tourists over coronavirus concerns
summary: Vietnam has announced it will stop issuing visas for Chinese tourists due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. The decision comes after three new cases were detected in the country, with all three individuals having recently returned from Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak. The move is part of broader measures to contain the spread of the virus, which has killed 170 people and is affecting global markets. The country's border gates with China have also halted imports and exports of goods until February 9.

site_title: Workforce Singapore ramps up reskilling efforts for electronics sector
summary: Workforce Singapore (WSG) has launched a reskilling initiative for the electronics sector, partnering with the Singapore Semiconductor Industry Association to upskill workers and companies. The Professional Conversion Programme will increase training capacity for electronics engineers and assistant engineers, and a new Place-and-Train Programme will equip mid-career operators with skills for enhanced roles. The programs aim to benefit 1,000 more professionals and prepare them for emerging opportunities in the industry.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Many countries are unprepared, says global health monitor
summary: A global health monitor warns that many countries are unprepared to face the deadly Wuhan virus, which has killed 170 people and infected over 8,000 in China and beyond. The Global Preparedness Monitoring Board urges governments to take immediate action to build essential preparedness capacities, including accelerating vaccine development, diagnostics, and therapeutics. The monitor also calls for additional funding to support the World Health Organization's response activities, particularly for lower-resourced countries.

site_title: Indonesia offers reward for plucking tyre off giant crocodile's neck
summary: Indonesian authorities are offering a reward to anyone who can safely rescue a 4m-long saltwater crocodile with a motorbike tyre stuck around its neck. The contest, aimed at ending years of failed attempts to untangle the reptile, will see a cash prize awarded to a brave croc hunter. Local conservation authorities have warned that only those with a background in wildlife rescue and a thirst for conservation should attempt the task, and the general public is advised not to disturb the crocodile's habitat.

site_title: Bowling: Cherie Tan wins Bowler of the Year gong at awards night
summary: Cherie Tan, 31, was named Singapore Bowling Federation's Bowler of the Year for the fourth time at their Chinese New Year dinner cum awards night. Tan's consistent achievements last year include winning the Masters title at the World Bowling women's championships and the Professional Women's Bowling Association Players Championship. She also captured the SEA Games women's team gold and the Storm-Domino's Pizza Cup in South Korea. Arianne Tay, 15, was named SBF's Youth Bowler of the Year for winning the Kaohsiung International Open Bowling Championship and the World Junior Bowling Championships.

site_title: Wuhan virus: South Korea reports first local human-to-human transmission
summary: South Korea reported its first local case of human-to-human transmission of the Wuhan virus, with two additional confirmed cases, bringing the total to six. The patients, including a 56-year-old man who was in contact with the third case, were diagnosed after either being in contact with the third patient or arriving from Wuhan, China, where the virus is believed to have originated. This marks the first local transmission outside of China, with cases also reported in Japan, Germany, Thailand, and Taiwan. International airlines have suspended or reduced services to China to halt the spread of the virus.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Get us out of here, plead South Asian students in Wuhan
summary: Foreign students in Wuhan, China, are urging their governments to evacuate them due to the coronavirus outbreak. Over 500 Pakistani students and their families, as well as 400 Bangladeshis, are stranded in the city. Pakistan's Health Minister stated that the country is following Chinese regulations and there are no current plans for evacuation. In contrast, the US has airlifted nearly 200 Americans from Wuhan, and South Korea is preparing evacuation flights. Students are growing increasingly anxious, with many calling for their governments to take action to rescue them.

site_title: Wuhan virus: British Airways escalates response with one-month China ban
summary: British Airways announced a one-month halt to flights to China, suspending services to Beijing and Shanghai up to February 29, 2020, following Foreign Office advice against non-essential travel. This move, along with other airlines such as Iberia and Deutsche Lufthansa, aims to address the growing concern over the deadly coronavirus outbreak. The World Health Organization is set to provide an update on whether the outbreak is a "public health emergency of international concern."

site_title: Dr Vivian Balakrishnan meets Malaysian ministers to discuss wide-ranging bilateral issues
summary: Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan made a working visit to Malaysia on Jan 30, 2020, meeting with various Malaysian ministers on bilateral issues. He discussed ways to strengthen ties between Singapore and Malaysia with Foreign Minister Saifuddin Abdullah, Water and Land Minister Xavier Jayakumar, Economic Affairs Minister Azmin Ali, Transport Minister Anthony Loke, and Home Affairs Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. The meetings aimed to address various bilateral issues, resulting in a strengthened relationship between the two countries.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Negative coronavirus test for passenger aboard locked down Italian cruise ship
summary: A 54-year-old woman on board the Costa Smeralda cruise ship, who showed flu-like symptoms, was tested negative for the new coronavirus, allowing passengers to disembark. The test was conducted at Rome's Spallanzani institute, confirming no infection. The World Health Organization declared the coronavirus epidemic in China a public health emergency of international concern, prompting countries to isolate citizens evacuated from Wuhan. Passengers on the ship reacted with varying emotions, while another European cruise company, MSC Crociere, announced it would deny access to its ships for anyone who visited mainland China in the past 30 days.

site_title: Coronavirus: Pofma exemptions lifted amid spread of fake news
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) exemptions for search engines and social media platforms, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, will be lifted on January 31. The move comes amid the spread of misinformation on the Wuhan coronavirus, with the Ministry of Communications and Information citing the need for accurate information to prevent panic. General correction directions, which require platforms to communicate correction notices to all users, will now apply to these platforms, following targeted corrections issued earlier for specific cases.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Thai health minister says sick PM Prayut does not have coronavirus
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha has cancelled some engagements due to symptoms resembling a cold, but health minister Anutin Charnvirakul denies he may have contracted the novel coronavirus. Prayut had visited the Bangkok airport to inspect screening measures, wearing a protective mask, and has continued to take calls and work despite his illness. Thailand has confirmed 14 cases of the virus, with 135 people under monitoring, and the country's tourism sector is under strain.

site_title: Wuhan virus: SBS Transit and SMRT step up cleaning efforts for buses and trains
summary: Public transport operators SBS Transit and SMRT in Singapore are increasing cleaning efforts for buses and trains amid the Wuhan virus situation. At bus interchanges, surfaces will be cleaned every 2 hours, while at train stations, they will be cleaned 3 times a day. Bus interiors will be disinfected weekly, and train interiors will be cleaned daily during engineering hours. Both operators are also using disinfectants on surfaces such as handrails, seats, and taps to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Temperature-takers on the front line
summary: Singaporean Grab driver Wilson Chan, 40, has started working as a freelance healthcare assistant, screening temperatures of inbound travelers at Changi Airport. Despite the risks, Chan has signed up for the role, which could put him in contact with infected individuals. Chan's work began on January 29, as the Wuhan virus outbreak continues to spread globally.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Mounting calls for ban on wildlife trade in Indonesia as coronavirus spreads globally
summary: Indonesia is facing mounting calls to ban its wildlife trade amid the growing Wuhan virus outbreak, which has killed at least 170 people and infected over 7,700 worldwide. Animal rights groups, including Dog Meat Free Indonesia, have urged President Joko Widodo to take preventive measures to mitigate the risks posed by Indonesia's animal markets, citing them as "the perfect breeding ground for new and deadly zoonotic viruses." The government is preparing to quarantine arriving passengers and has tracked suspected cases, but concerns remain about the potential spread of the virus through the country's vast archipelago.

site_title: Enhanced safety measures for Chingay Parade 2020 amid Wuhan virus concerns
summary: Singapore's Chingay Parade 2020 will take place as planned on Jan 31-32 despite Wuhan virus concerns. Enhanced safety measures have been implemented, including daily temperature checks, thermal scanners, and on-site medical personnel. Six performers from China have been cleared to participate after screening by a doctor. The event will feature 5G technology and a livestream of the world's longest and largest dragon performance. Spectators are advised to check their temperature and seek medical attention if necessary, and those unable to attend can watch online.

site_title: Tennis: Novak Djokovic downs Roger Federer in straight sets to reach Australian Open final
summary: Novak Djokovic defeated Roger Federer in a straight sets win at the Australian Open, 7-6 (7-1), 6-4, 6-3, to reach the final. This was their 50th match and Djokovic's 27th win over Federer. The Serb struggled with his service games but regained control to win the sets. Djokovic will face the winner of the other semi-final between Alexander Zverev and Dominic Thiem in the final on Sunday.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Bus, train services unaffected by small number of drivers on leave of absence
summary: A small number of drivers, around 30, from bus and train operators in Singapore are on a 14-day leave of absence due to travel to China during the Chinese New Year period, where the Wuhan virus outbreak started. The move aims to minimize the risk of spreading the virus. Despite this, public transport operations remain unaffected, as the affected workers are not deployed for front-line duties. The Land Transport Authority and ComfortDelGro Corp, which operates in China, are taking precautions to protect staff and customers, including providing masks and disinfectants.

site_title: Wuhan virus: Russia to shut border with China, stop issuing electronic visas to Chinese nationals
summary: Russia has closed its border with China to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus and stopped issuing electronic visas to Chinese nationals. The decision was made by Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin, citing a need to protect the Russian people. Russia has no confirmed cases of the virus, but a task force has been set up to prevent its possible spread. The Russian foreign ministry also advised Russians to avoid traveling to China and those in China to contact the Russian embassy.

site_title: Football: Temperature checks at Chiam See Tong Sports Fund Charity Shield
summary: Temperature checks will be conducted at the entrance of Our Tampines Hub ahead of the Chiam See Tong Sports Fund Charity Shield football match on Jan 31, 2020, due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. Over 200 tickets have been sold for the match between Celebrities Sports Club and Singapore Ex-Internationals. Organisers have advised fans to stay home if feeling unwell and will refund tickets if necessary. The event aims to raise funds for disadvantaged children and youth to achieve their sporting dreams, and measures have been taken to ensure a safe environment for attendees.

site_title: Coronavirus: Govt cracks down on mask profiteers, retailer Deen Express queried on alleged inflated prices
summary: The Singapore government is cracking down on retailers profiteering from the COVID-19 pandemic by selling face masks at inflated prices. A retailer, Deen Express, was queried by the Government's Price Controller over alleged price hikes of up to 3 times the usual cost. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has issued letters of demand to e-commerce platforms Lazada, Carousell, and Qoo10, warning of fines up to $20,000 for non-compliance. The government urges consumers not to support profiteers, while e-commerce platforms have pledged to cooperate and remove listings of unreasonable prices.

site_title: Tennis: Sofia Kenin keeps believing to reach maiden Grand Slam final
summary: Sofia Kenin advanced to her first Grand Slam final at the Australian Open after defeating Ashleigh Barty in a thrilling semi-final match. Despite trailing for most of the match, Kenin remained confident and composed, eventually coming from behind to win in a tiebreaker. The 21-year-old American cited her determination and focus as key factors in her victory, saying she was "fighting" and "left everything on the court." Kenin's win marks a significant milestone in her career, as she prepares to face the world number one in the final.

site_title: Asian Insider Jan 30: Human rights and politics complicate the fight against Wuhan Virus
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The Wuhan virus outbreak has raised concerns about human rights and politics. In Japan, two citizens refused health checks after being flown home from Wuhan, citing lack of legal basis to force them to undergo tests. In the US, mask hoarders are exacerbating the risk of an outbreak. In Asia, protests and border closures have erupted, with Hong Kong, South Korea, and Malaysia taking measures to contain the spread. Meanwhile, China reported 38 new deaths and over 1,700 infected patients. The crisis highlights the complexities of fighting the virus, with politics and human rights playing a significant role.

site_title: Wuhan virus: India reports its first case of coronavirus
summary: India reports its first case of coronavirus, with a patient in Kerala testing positive for the novel virus. The patient, a student of Wuhan University, is stable and in isolation. The Indian government had prepared to evacuate nationals from Wuhan but was waiting for Chinese authorities' approval. The country has so far not reported any fatalities from the virus, which has killed 170 globally.

site_title: White House adviser Jared Kushner says he hopes Israel waits before moving to annex West Bank
summary: White House senior adviser Jared Kushner has expressed hope that Israel will wait until after its March 2 election to make any moves towards settlement annexation in the West Bank. Kushner, architect of the US peace plan, stated that Washington wants Israel to wait and work with them to come up with a solution. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has announced plans to apply Israeli law to Jewish settlements in the West Bank, which could be a step towards formal annexation.
